TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Solar Energy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is widespread community concern regarding
1. the almost total dependence in Australia on fossil, fuel, and their deleterious effects in producing the greenhouse phenomenon in the environment;
2. the proposal to spend millions of dollars on research into nuclear power, the production of which has in other countries proven expensive and dangerous; and
3. the lack of adequate funding for research into, and promotion of alternative renewable sources of energy, in particular, solar power.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. fund adequate research into production of large scale solar energy for industry; and
2. encourage the use of known technology for hot water and space heating by tax incentives on solar heating equipment for houses and commercial buildings.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

support both the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of electors, and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public;
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent and Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys- General, most womens' groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ETHICAL BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, eight sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee be appointed, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on the Ethical Behaviour of Members of Parliament.
(2) That the Committee:
(a) inquire into and report upon the ethical standards of behaviour to which Members of Parliament should conform;
(b) draw up and publish a code of ethics to be considered for adoption by each House of the Parliament; and

(c) on adoption by a House of a code of ethics, report to that House, on the first sitting day of that House that is not more than 12 months after the date of adoption of the code by that House, and thereafter not less frequently than every 12 months, on:
(i) the general operation of the code of ethics, and
(ii) whether any changes should be made to the code and, if so, what those changes should be and why they are needed.
(3) That the Committee consist of 10 members, as follows:
(a) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats;
(d) 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister; and
(e) 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition.
(4) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(5) That if, within 5 sitting days of the House of Representatives after transmission of this Resolution to the House, the House of Representatives has not concurred in this Resolution, or no members of the House of Representatives have been appointed to the Committee, then the Committee operate as a select committee of the Senate with a quorum of 3, and these terms of reference be read accordingly.
(6) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Prime Minister.

(7) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee, being a non-government member from the other House, to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That the quorum of the Committee be 5 members.

(10) That the Committee, and any sub-committee, have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(11) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all the members appointed to the sub-committee.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(14) That the Committee report to each House of Parliament on or before the first day of sitting of that House in April 1990 on the matters referred to in sub-paragraphs 2 (a) and (b) of this resolution.
(15) That, subject to paragraph 5, the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(16) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
(17) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be communicated by Message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney and pursuant to his contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney from moving a motion relating to the Order of Business on the Notice Paper, namely, a motion to give precedence to Government Business Order of the Day No. 6, relating to the National Health Amendment Bill 1989.

I will speak briefly to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Anybody looking at yesterday's Notice Paper would have observed that the orders of the day under the heading Government Business read as follows:
No. 1-Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989
No. 2-National Health Amendment Bill 1989
No. 3-Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988
Anybody looking at today's Senate Notice Paper will find under the heading of Government Business that, now that we have disposed of the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill, Orders of the Day read:
No. 1-Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988.
No. 2-Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90.
No. 3-Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90.
No. 4-Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90.
No. 5-Advance to the Minister for Finance 1988-89-Statement of Expenditure.
No. 6-National Health Amendment Bill 1989.

Today a large number of pharmacists, particularly female pharmacists and women employed in pharmacies around Australia, have come to Canberra for the purpose of indicating to the Government their dissatisfaction with the way in which the Government has been dealing with matters of pharmacy and with questions relating to the provisions of remuneration for pharmacists. These matters are dealt with in the National Health Amendment Bill and in the amendment made by the Senate when this matter was debated on 27 September. The purpose of our moving for the suspension of Standing Orders is to facilitate the moving of a motion to deal now with the question of the National Health Amendment Bill and the remuneration of pharmacists.

We believe this is a matter which should be determined as quickly as possible. After all, to put this legislation on the Notice Paper after we have allegedly dealt with the Budget will mean that the matter will not be resolved for many months. We believe that pharmacists have to a very large extent been made the scapegoats in this debate-a matter which I shall come to if the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is carried. Nevertheless, I do not propose to speak at any length about the reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders. It is quite simple: we wish to have the National Health Amendment Bill and the Senate amendment to that Bill dealt with as expeditiously as possible. We believe, therefore, that the Standing Orders should be suspended. If they are suspended, we should then debate the National Health Amendment Bill, determine what the Senate's position on that matter is and then proceed to the other matters which are on the Notice Paper. I therefore seek support for the suspension of Standing Orders and, if that is carried, I will move to bring on debate on the National Health Amendment Bill forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. From time to time a great deal of criticism has been levelled at Canberra being remote from the capital cities around Australia, where most constituents live. Today, there are a large number of pharmacists in Canberra. They have made a very specific, deliberate and costly effort to be in Canberra to demonstrate their opposition to the Government's changes to pharmacy remuneration. It is very appropriate that this matter be debated today so that those people present in the gallery can be aware of the proceedings in the Senate and, in that way, can participate in the proper democratic process. To deny them that opportunity by putting this matter off for further weeks and months would be quite inappropriate. Therefore, there is considerable pressure for supporting the suspension of Standing Orders so that this matter may be debated now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that any Government Minister would oppose the re-ordering of Government Business. Indeed, very serious reasons must be given for Standing Orders to be suspended to allow the order of business to be changed. Before I deal with the arguments of the Opposition, let me say that I have just heard one of the most stupid and idiotic statements ever made in this chamber. We have been told that this chamber should debate a certain matter because people have arrived in Canberra. This chamber determines its priorities, not people who come into the gallery. That is an absolutely ridiculous statement.
—But taking it off because they are coming to Canberra is all right?

—If Senator Baume's party ever returns to government, does he in his heart believe that Government Business should be determined by who is going to arrive in Canberra on a particular day? He would say, `No, absolutely not'. That is a ridiculous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I can listen to and disagree with some of the points that were made by Senator Puplick and I will do so. But Senator Coulter has come in here and proposed that we should debate something today simply because people with a self-interest have turned up. When Vietnam demonstrations were being held outside the old Parliament House in the 1960s, would Senator Baume have come into this place and argued that we must debate the Vietnam war because people outside were protesting against it? It is absolutely preposterous to suggest that the timing of debates in this chamber is related to what lobbyists are outside. That is an absolutely pathetic suggestion. Senator Coulter even said that the debate should be held today because people have gone to the cost of coming here.

It is a pity that we were not given a little more notice that a motion would be moved to suspend Standing Orders. However, I thank Senator Puplick for giving me some notice because I have to recall a Minister who is not here but delivering a speech somewhere else. I do not know whether he will be back for this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not make any difference if he were.

—That is a typical attitude by Senator Knowles. One of the great democrats of the Parliament says that it does not matter. As far as I am concerned, the reality is that one of the few privileges this Government has in this chamber is ordering its own business. That has always been the case. How many times from 1975 to 1983 was the placing of business taken out of the hands of the Government? How many times was such a motion moved?
—That shows how urgent this is.

—Do not get pathetic, Senator Sheil. If those opposite were ever to win government again they would always maintain the right to list Government Business according to their own priorities. It may just be-I have not been privy to whether this debate goes on today or not-that one of the strongest arguments for its not going on today is that there might be people here putting views that would influence government, but all those opposite are intent on is putting on a performance for the gallery. That is what this is about-so that members of the Opposition can put on a performance because an election is coming up. They have asked for honesty before; the Senator Baumes demand honesty. Why do they not get up and say that that is the reason they want to debate this matter today?
—And you are taking it off because there is an election coming up?
—We have the right as a government to consider the business in the order in which the Government wants to put it forward.
—In the light of the coming election.

—No, I am just saying that that is one of the rights-the Senate has other rights-usually accorded to government. Members of the Opposition have broken that today which is something that they will regret one day because it was never done to them when they were in government. They ordered their own business. The people sitting in this chamber since 1974 and 1975-and there are three or four of them here-know that they always had the right in that period to schedule business in their own order according to their own legislative program. This is another example of this chamber eating more and more into any government rights. It is often said that it is the Executive or the Government eating into the chamber's rights, but there is a balance, those opposite know there is a balance and they know that today they are tipping that balance in a particular way whereby this chamber will lose its relevance. One of the relevant factors of this chamber is still a legislative program. All the other rights are there to speak, divert and waste time, but one of the reasons this chamber still exists-to go back to the founding fathers-is to pass legislation. We seem to have lost our way on that. I think that we have carried three pieces of legislation in six weeks. We have something like 91 Bills of an urgent nature still to come.
—If they pull this trick we will support you in cutting them off at the knees, too.

—That is the pathetic point about it. What the honourable senator is virtually indicating to me is that when the present Government goes out of office the Australian Democrats will support us in the same grubby tactic. That is what he is saying. I am asking those opposite to reflect on this suspension of Standing Orders because it is not just a question of one day's opportunism. The question at heart is: Does the Government have the right to consider its own legislative program according to its own timetable? It is something we never sought to prevent when we sat on the other side of the House because it was one of the balances in this chamber. The Opposition had Question Time, Estimates committees, the adjournment, private business and matters of public importance. All those things balanced it off. One of the few things the government had to balance it off was that it was entitled to put its program in its own way.
—Will you tell us why you had a change of heart between yesterday and today?

—I will come to that in a moment. I am just saying what the principle is. I was asked some time yesterday, not today, whether the Government wanted more time to consider these matters. I was asked whether, if the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill finished yesterday, we would move on to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill. I had the motion prepared yesterday. Little did I realise that the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill would blow out all day, and it did. I do not think anyone in this chamber realistically expected the banking Bill to go through until 10.30 p.m. Had it finished at 9.30 p.m. or 8.30 p.m., I would have moved--
—That is one of the most controversial issues.

—Let us be honest, the banking issue is controversial; the banking Bill was not. Let us not get into these absolutely false debating stances. If the banking Bill had finished at 8.30 or 9 o'clock last night, I would have moved that we go on to the electoral Bill. The request came in yesterday; it did not come in late last night or this morning. This is the first time I can remember in my time in the chamber and from my reading of debates back to 1975 that it has been decided to reorder the priorities of the Government's legislative timetable in the Government's time. Plenty of other devices are available to debate matters in this chamber and they are used extensively. The opportunists in the Liberal Party will have a little laugh today, but they have a problem-and I agree with Senator McLean. He put the nail right into it when he said, `Right, they have done that to you today. Don't worry; sometime down the track you will do it back to them'.
—If they pull the same crude trick.

—Let us go to the same crude trick. As I have indicated, it is not as though it was decided late last night or this morning not to proceed with this matter; it was decided yesterday when the Government indicated to me that it needed more time to consider it. I do not really care whether honourable senators opposite take my word for it. A couple of other people here, who are not politically motivated, prepared for me the motion to defer the health matter yesterday and to move on to the electoral Bill. I would have thought that the people who prepared those motions were paid to be neutral in this place. It was not as though this was just done this morning, as some honourable senators allege.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not waste much more of the time of the chamber. I think a precedent is being set today that people on that side of the chamber may live to regret. I cannot guarantee that they will regret it because I cannot guarantee that people on this side of the chamber will drop to that level, as we believe that there should be a balance in this place between government legislation and the rights of honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to that right last week in our time?
—It was in everyone's time. We went through that debate last week or the week before. If honourable senators opposite want to rip up the normal conventions, let them rip them up.
—You ripped them up last week.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist on amendments Nos 1 and 2 made by the Senate, to which the House of Representatives has disagreed, and agrees to the Amendment and the consequential Amendment made by the House of Representatives in place of Amendment No. 1.

In speaking to the motion, I do not wish to canvass any great length the proceedings of the previous debate. Suffice it to say that this debate was scheduled for a later time this day and, working on that understanding, I was not present in the chamber when this matter was called on at short notice.

I open my remarks on the motion by picking up a point made by Senator Ray as he was concluding his speech. It seems now that the gallery is sufficiently full for the opportunistic actions of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to be able to be proceeded with. This signifies the absolute paucity and ineptitude of the Opposition and I hope that all Australians can see their actions today.

Government is not about yielding to the sorts of pressure group power that we now see operating in this place. Government is about working for the whole of the community. What was said earlier by the Australian Democrats, when Senator Ray was debating the motion, that we were somehow working in an elevated political plane simply because there were constituents in the gallery, is, I would put it, rubbish. There is a pressure group in the gallery with a particular point of view that it wants to put forcibly on this Government. That pressure group wants to prevail against the interests of the wider community in this country.

I want it on the record, up front, right now, that what this Government is not about is yielding to the puny pressure of individual groups that are motivated by self-interest. What this Government is about is governing in the interests of the wider community and taking the responsibility of our mandate on behalf of all Australians. That is what this Government is about and the sorry, sordid excursion into political opportunism in this place does not in any case reflect credit on the Opposition which aspires to being the alternative Government. It enshrines in public understanding the belief that the Opposition, if ever given the reins of government, will take the short term, the expedient and the superficial route. If faced with either the hard option or the soft option, it will take the soft option all the time. There is no better example of this than what we have here today in the chamber. We also had a recent example just the other week when the Opposition's economic policy came out and we saw an attempt to exploit, for purely crass and short term political gain, the economic reform that the Hawke Labor Government has built in this country. I will now turn to the motion rather than the means by which that motion has been brought before this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean you're going to give us substance?

—Substance is foreign to Senator Bishop. Substance is alien and strange to her. If the motion I have moved is not carried, we will see a triumph of greed and avarice over proper process and public responsibility. If this motion is not carried we will see that it is indeed possible for the wider interests of all Australians to be manipulated by the scientific pressure of a few. If this motion is not carried we will see Opposition members hanging themselves out like prostitutes to pick up what votes they can on the street corner in order to try to topple what is a--

SPEECH.PARA: The debate that we are about to have ignores history. In 1981 it was a Liberal-Michael MacKellar-who introduced legislation for there to be an independent arbitration on pharmaceutical fees. It was a Liberal Party initiative. This initiative grew out of a procedure before the Public Accounts Committee because there was widespread public concern about the way in which those fees had been set in the past, the process by which they had been set and the outrageous amount of public money, taxpayers' money, that was being spent in this area. So a prudent measure, which was supported by us in opposition, emanated from the Fraser Government. If this matter goes to a vote, some members of the Opposition will vote against the spirit of the MacKellar Bill when, at the time of its introduction, they voted for it. If that be a definition of hypocrisy, let it be seen to be that. If this motion is not carried, we are asking this chamber to overturn one of the precepts upon which the MacKellar Bill was based-that is, that decisions of an independent tribunal be binding.

Back in 1981-and let the Hansard record stand as true testimony to what was said then-that precept was relied on as being the substantial cornerstone precept in the whole proceedings. We, as a Government, have accepted that precept-the Fraser Government precept; the precept originating out of hearings of the Public Accounts Committee and one that we supported at the time. If one is to have an independent inquiry into fees one must accept the independent outcome; otherwise the process is a sham, it can be manipulated by power or pressure groups and it is a shield for political football and sordid political manoeuvre. That point was made then and it remains shiningly true today. But we are now facing the possibility of its being overturned. We, in government, have done nothing more than accept the precepts under which the MacKellar Bill was adopted by this Parliament in 1981. That is all we have done. When we hear the argument, `Why does the Government not overturn the legislation?' we point to the arguments made by Liberals back then and say that if this is done, and those decisions are able to be overridden politically, the argument no longer depends on merit; the argument depends on political power. One cannot make decisions, as the airline pilots in this country know, based on who has the biggest stick; one has to make decisions based on merit and principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much are you giving Abeles?
—What was that interjection? The honourable senator has forgotten his own interjection. If he does not have the courage to repeat it or he cannot remember it, I will not answer it.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of the concern expressed by the proper organisations accredited to represent pharmacists, those organisations met the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, and later the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As a consequence of that round of discussions, the organisations accepted an agreement, as reported, that the determination of the Pharmaceutical Remuneration Benefits Tribunal would stand and that they would look for other areas of negotiation, which they then committed themselves to, to settle their claims. This motion should pass because, in the properly structured negotiations with no less than the Prime Minister of this nation, it was accepted that the determination should stand. That was accepted by the advocates and appointed leaders of the pharmacists themselves. If it does stand, albeit that we have amended it to make it operative from 1 January, not 1 October, proper negotiations can flow. Therefore, it is not now a matter of this chamber deciding whether it should try to work the Government over to help the pharmacists; that is not the issue here. It is not a matter either of believing the pharmacists and not the independent tribunal and wanting the pharmacists to win. The issue that this chamber has to consider is whether there will be a proper process; whether Rafferty's rules or the proper rules will be laid down.

Irrespective of the type of energy being generated by the protest out front and now in the chamber, there is a consideration more fundamental in this motion. It does not matter whether one believes the pharmacists or supports them against the wider community. What matters is that the process to be followed is rational, logical and something that the Opposition, were it in government, would be able to follow also.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be, and we will do better.

—Those opposite will not be in government; they just will not. I have made this point because if it is possible for a group to negotiate with the Prime Minister of this nation, irrespective of the political party from which that Prime Minister comes, reach an agreement and then abrogate that agreement, where does the proper process of government in this country stand? If the Opposition does not vote to support a proper process along those lines, it is consigning such a process to the wastepaper basket. The Minister has proposed that there be further negotiations to settle some of the claims. Indeed, he has made offers. What has he received in reply to those offers? He has received demands which reflect a more avaricious approach to this issue from the pharmacists than obtained before.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition parties are faced with a simple choice of the plutocrats and the people, the phoneys and the pharmacists or the cronies and the chemists we will decide, on each occasion, on behalf of those people in the community who are attempting to earn an honest, decent living; providing services to the Australian community under extreme pressure and being victimised by an incompetent and failed government. The Opposition will stand with them and use whatever forms are available to it, in this chamber or elsewhere, to defend their position and promote their interests.

It is not as if this is an unusual procedure. If one looks back to the days when Senator Lionel Murphy was the Leader of the Opposition, and the government of the day did not have a clear majority, attempts to reorganise the business-take it out of the hands of the Government and put it into the hands of the Opposition-were not infrequent. If Senator Ray wants to know why it was that this reorganisation did not take place during the period that Sir John Carrick was the Leader of the Government and Senator Messner was a Minister, he ought to contemplate the fact that for a very large period of that time it was the Government that actually had the numbers in the chamber and, therefore, was able to ensure that there was not a reorganisation of the business of the chamber.

This motion by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has two elements. The first disagrees with an amendment made to the National Health Amendment Bill by the Senate on 27 September. The second agrees to a House of Representatives amendment which changes the commencement date of the increase in the maximum patient contribution from $11 to $12. That was originally scheduled to take place on 1 October. It had to be changed because of the passage of the amendment to the Bill and the Government is now seeking to have that amendment apply as of 1 January. The Opposition asks for this motion to be taken in two parts. We do not disagree with House of Representatives amendment No. 1, which relates to the change of the commencement date, and we are prepared to support the Government in agreeing to that amendment. But we will insist on the Senate amendment and, therefore, vote against that part of the Minister's motion which asks the Committee not to persist with its amendment.

What is the Senate's amendment? The amendment is quite simply to strike down, in legislative form, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT) determination of 28 August. The Opposition believes that that determination is flawed, is wrong and should not be allowed to stand. Because it cannot be disallowed by any means other than the passage of legislation through both Houses of the Parliament we now invite the Senate to join with the Opposition in striking down that determination of 28 August.

A couple of points need to be made about this. The first is that, in essence, the Government is seeking to transfer the responsibility for its own incapacity to maintain the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) on to the shoulders of the pharmacists of Australia. The Government has failed fundamentally to address the underlying issues in the pharmaceutical scheme. It has failed to respond to the fact that there is a blow-out in costs. That blow-out in costs could well have been anticipated. The largest component of that blow-out in costs results from a change in the Australian population. The fact is that in 1986-87, 59.3 per cent of the payments made under the scheme were made to pensioners, a figure of $514m. By 1988-89 that had risen to 70.2 per cent, and a figure of $797m. That increase was clearly capable of being anticipated as the population aged.

What steps has the Government put in place to come to some understanding and accommodation of that problem? For example, has it looked at the items that are covered by the scheme? When the scheme was originally introduced by the Menzies Government in the early 1950s it was a safety net to allow people access to life-saving drugs. At the moment, there are things such as analgesics, eye drops and antacids on the list which may, or may not, be appropriate to be maintained on the list in terms of what really are life saving drugs.

In 1986 the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reported on the whole operation of the scheme. None of the major recommendations of the IAC report was picked up and acted upon by the Government. The Government has had before it the dimensions of the problem, the financial consequences of leaving the system unaltered, the recommendations of the IAC report and, indeed, a number of other reports with which I will not deal today. It has not sought fundamentally to restructure the scheme in a way which will address the budgetary implications which it says are its primary concern. Instead, it has decided to make individual pharmacists the scapegoat for its own incompetent behaviour.

It has penalised them as it has penalised almost no other section in the community. In September 1987 it moved to reduce the wholesale margin from 15 per cent to 10 per cent. Under its new arrangements it is now moving to make further changes to abolish mark-ups in most areas and wind back and reduce the remuneration paid to pharmacists, and that much is admitted all round. There is absolutely no doubt that pharmacists are to have their remuneration cut. For example, the statement issued on 22 October by Dr Blewett talks about the new flat rate mark-up of an average of 53 per cent. That particular mark-up is most misleading. Dr Blewett admits that there will be a cut to the remuneration of the pharmacists from the introduction of the new scheme which he describes as, at most, `only a third of the amount in question'-that is, from $1.05 to 35c.

Let us remember what has happened to the patient contribution. When this Government came into office the maximum patient contribution for pharmaceutical products was $4. This Bill will now take it to $12. In other words, under the way in which this Government has conducted the pharmaceutical remuneration scheme and the PBS scheme as a whole, since 1983 the Government has managed to raise the maximum patient contribution from $4 to $12. The Government is still not content with believing that it should do anything other than adopt this purely confrontationist attitude with a group of skilled and dedicated professionals in the community. The Government has ended any attempt, any pretence, that it governs by consensus. The Prime Minister has decided to abuse pharmacists in exactly the same way as he abuses pilots or anybody else who will not become part and parcel of whatever temporary deal he wishes to stitch up at any particular moment in order to prop up his Government and to prop up the arrangements which he wishes to put into place.

I propose to take a little more time on this matter because one of the issues I want to raise is this question of campaigns. Senator Cook proclaims himself an expert campaigner. I do not know who precisely was responsible for the publication of this pamphlet The truth and nothing but the truth about the cost and supply of prescription medicine. There has never been a document of such a tendentious nature as this. The Government has entered into a campaign with advertisements in the newspapers. If people had phoned the hot line numbers that appeared in the advertisements they would have got absolutely no assistance from whoever was on the other end of the hot line. They did not know anything. Perhaps it was that they did not know anything or perhaps it was that they were not prepared to be part of the lies and misinformation which the Government has sought to put out in relation to this particular pamphlet. I propose to go through some of the assertions in this pamphlet. I shall certainly be seeking the assistance of my colleague in a moment to intervene to allow me to continue. Let me look at a couple of those--

—No, we are in committee.
—Now look, get your Standing Orders under control.

—I understand that Senator Cook does not really understand the issues of the debate but the fact--

—I refer to the first assertion that the PBRT decision represented only a 23 per cent cut in pharmacy incomes. Only a 23 per cent cut-is that not a wonderful idea? That 23 per cent cut was in gross payments which directly equates to a 60 per cent cut in net profits for most people in this industry. The Government then asserted that there was an average subsidy-note that word `subsidy'-that the Government provides to each pharmacy of over $100,000 a year. It is not a subsidy. It is, in fact, a payment the pharmacies are entitled to for rendering a service on behalf of the Government to people in the community as people who are, themselves, primary health care providers and whose role as such is integral and important to the maintenance of public health in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The pamphlet then goes on to make assertions about over $1 billion being paid out under the scheme. That may be correct but of that $1 billion it ought to be remembered that only about 16 per cent was given by way of an increase to pharmacists. The 89 per cent-the blow-out in most of the rest of the area-represents increased payments to manufacturers. That is not stated. That is not indicated in the pamphlet. That is misleading. The Government asserts that it is committed to ensure that Australians, no matter where they live, continue to have access to pharmacists. The pamphlet then goes on to describe the PBRT report as having been concluded after an extensive study, including 600 submissions. There may have been 600 submissions but people will know from the debates that we have had about pharmacy in this place for some considerable time that the response to the questionnaire upon which the PBRT based most of its determination was absolutely derisory and simply could not sustain the conclusions to which the PBRT came in its ultimate decision. The Government then asserts that the pharmacists will not accept the umpire's decision. Let the Minister, who is responsible as a member of a Government for the rort of the postage allowances and for fiddling with the Remuneration Tribunal's determination for cheap political purposes whenever it suits the Government's convenience, get up in here and talk about adhering to the decision of the umpire. One thing that this Government cannot claim is to adhere to the decisions of the umpire. In exactly the same way as with the pilots, the Government will not even let the umpire pronounce on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Graeme Campbell-an extraordinary and honest member of the Australian Labor Party-managed to send a letter to his colleagues a little while ago about this matter. In relation to Mr Staples, Mr Campbell, the Labor backbencher, said:
It is my view that this confrontationist and emotional atmosphere is being generated by some of the absurdities coming from the Minister's office.

That is what a Labor backbencher thinks of his Minister-putting out absurdities. One of the absurdities that Senator Cook has been putting out today is this business that pharmacists are misusing their position, that they are frightening people in the community and that the sick, the elderly and the unwell are unsure and uncertain. Of course people are unsure and uncertain. They understand that this Government is determined to pursue a war against the pharmacists and against the people who practise the profession of pharmacy because it is unable and unwilling to tackle the structural and underlying problems which exist within the pharmaceutical benefits scheme as it operates at the moment. We have all this backing and filling as far as the Government is concerned.

Honourable senators will recall that there was an announcement some weeks ago that the Government was going to defer all of this. In fact, there was some light at the end of the tunnel at the end of September when the negotiations between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild took place. But why was there a discussion between the Guild and the Government? On the very day that the Opposition parties in this chamber introduced an amendment to the National Health Amendment Bill to strike down the 28 August determination, the Government suddenly rang the Guild and said, `Please come and have a talk to us'. It knew that the Senate was not going to cop it sweet as far as its attack upon the pharmacists was concerned. So there was a meeting between the Guild and the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister indicated that there would be scope for delay, that the system would not come into place until 1 November. Indeed, on 4 October the Prime Minister told Federal Caucus that there would be scope for both parties to approach the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal after the November deadline if the dispute was not settled. The prospect that there would be some resolution was held out by the Prime Minister. However, we then find that within a few days of that the Prime Minister decided to beat his chest and to put the pharmacists in the same category as the pilots by saying, `No negotiations, no compromise'.

One suspects that the Prime Minister simply misread his brief that morning which said, `Get out there and kick pilots'. He misread it and went out and kicked pharmacists. Having fallen into that signal error, he said that there will be no compromise, that he is not going to be pushed around and that Mr Staples, who has the great advantage of having failed first year pharmacy, is going to go out there and fix them all up. All of a sudden we will find that there is going to be no attempt to negotiate and deal with this matter in a civilised and proper fashion.

People have been sent out to undertake a government-funded survey-a secret survey which attempts to portray pharmacists in a poor light by saying that there is overcharging. If one reads the details of what is supposed to be in that survey, one can see that it quite simply says, `Where a prescription drug is on the maximum patient contribution, that is charged in 93 per cent of cases. Where the patient contribution is less than the maximum, a large number of pharmacists charge the maximum price available'. This is the sort of behaviour in the marketplace that anybody would understand and nobody would be surprised at because it is taking place at the very time that the Government is otherwise attempting to reduce the incomes of pharmacists and cut the remuneration which is available to them. The Government is not going to get away with that shabby trick either. I conclude by putting squarely--

TALK.START.PARA: —About time.

—If the Minister provokes me, we will wait until a couple more senators have spoken and I will have another go at him. So I suggest that Senator Cook sit quietly because we can go as long as we like on this matter. I want to talk about the services currently being provided by pharmacists which we regard as absolutely critical and central as far as the public health system of this country is concerned. Pharmacists provide a first stop for a lot of people who want to make inquiries about preventive health care. This country is sadly negligent and deficient in the investment which goes into preventive medicine. SPEECH.PARA: Areas of relative weakness include preventative and community medicine . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are really only two points which need to be made most strongly in this debate: firstly, that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal got it wrong when it considered the remuneration for pharmacists; and, secondly, that the Government is seeking to hide behind that decision and not exercise its proper prerogative which is to review that decision and, if that decision is unsatisfactory, to do something about it. That is what lies at the core of this debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply untrue that the Government has accepted the recommendations and reports of other independent bodies. Indeed, in 1986, dealing with this particular industry, the Industries Assistance Commission recommended, firstly, that wholesale and retail margins not be regulated; secondly, that pharmacists be able to vary their margin according to market forces; and, thirdly, that pharmacists be free to advertise their prices. The Government accepted none of these recommendations. It is certainly well within the competence, the rights and the historical experience of this Government to reject totally recommendations from independent tribunals when it believes that those tribunals have simply got it wrong or have reported in ways which are unacceptable to the Government.

The next point that needs to be made is that, while the Government, through Minister Staples, has held out to pharmacists a period of negotiation, it is absolutely clear that there has not been good faith on the part of the Government. The Government has made it clear that it is not prepared to negotiate the terms of the Tribunal's determination. Frankly, I do not know how one can engage in a Clayton's negotiation-a negotiation while not really negotiating. It is not surprising in the light of that predetermined position by the Minister that the so-called negotiations have been remarkably unfruitful because clearly the Government was not prepared to change. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has said that the Government was seeking to work around the determination; in other words, to try to pick up in these negotiations aspects which were not covered by the Tribunal. How arbitrary it is to accept the core of a tribunal's determination and then try to find things on the fringes around which one can work and negotiate. If that process becomes necessary-a necessity accepted by the Government because it is one evidently entered into by the Government-it becomes equally obvious that the Tribunal's determination in the first place was wrong and therefore should have been changed.

As we pointed out when we debated this matter in the committee stage the last time it was before us, the Government should have accepted the amendment which was put by the Opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats, which was to reject the Remuneration Tribunal's determination. That would have cleared the decks and the Government could have gone into proper negotiation with all matters open and come up with a properly considered position.

Beyond that point we are substantially going over ground which has been debated in the previous debate on this matter. Since then we have seen an excellent report from the Legislative Research Service, by John Gardiner-Garden from the education and welfare group, on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the pharmaceutical industry. A number of the points made in that report underline and amplify points which were made in the earlier debate. It is absolutely clear-it was clear then and it is even clearer now-that the increasing cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) is not due to and cannot be controlled in any way by pharmacists. The increasing cost of the PBS is due to the change in the nature and the number of prescriptions which are written and those matters are under the control of the doctors. The pharmacists have no control in those matters whatsoever. The report goes to some lengths to point out that the costs of pharmaceuticals in Australia in relation to their costs overseas are extremely low; indeed, even the prescription cost to the patient as a percentage of average weekly earnings is very low by comparison with other countries. The report states:
The average price of an Australian prescription has dropped from 6.6% of average weekly earnings in 1955 to around 2% in 1989 (compared with 4.2% in the UK and 4.3% in the US).

In other words, even the cost of a prescription on average is less than half what it is in the United Kingdom or in the United States. That refers to the cost of PBS drugs, in terms of both the Government contribution and the patient contribution. The costs of drugs have increased and prescribing habits have changed. We have certainly moved from the use of cheaper drugs in particular treatments to more expensive drugs-a matter again not controlled by the pharmacists but one which is within the control of doctors and their prescribing habits.

As long ago as September 1988 I called for a complete review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to look at the efficacy of these drugs compared with the efficacy of drugs which they have replaced but, more importantly, compared with the efficacy of preventative measures and other measures which may avoid totally the use of the more expensive treatments. The report from the Legislative Research Service deals with a very interesting example of this change in prescribing habits and its effect on the cost to the PBS. In dealing with the two groups of drugs, the anti-hypertensives and the anti-hyperlipidaemics the report states:

In 1988-89 Antihypertensives cost the Government $127m and the Anti Hyperlipidaemics $26m (about 14% of the total bill), including patient contributions of $12.3m and $3m respectively (about 9% of total patient contributions). The Ace Inhibitors Captoprit and Enalapril Maleate cost $42.1m (including patient contribution . . . so in 1989-90 these two Anti-hypertensives alone, although on the Authority list, cost the community nearly $100m, a significant proportion of that year's total PBS budget.
That is certainly a very significant proportion for two drugs only. The report continues:
For all this expense, the benefits of Anti-hypertensives and Anti Hyperlipidaemics are disputed.

Even if one were to accept the benefits which flow from those drugs, clearly when one is looking at such a large percentage of total PBS costs and at a substantial increase as a consequence of the move to the use of these drugs, one needs also to look at the benefits. The report continues:
More cost-effective way of reducing the risk of heart disease include discouraging smoking, promoting reduced salt and fat intake and encouraging the maintenance of physical fitness.

That was precisely the point that I was making in September 1988 when I called for a thorough review of the PBS in the context of alternative modalities of treatment which did not involve the use of drugs. We may well find that the costs of the PBS could be substantially reduced and the numbers of prescriptions for the more expensive drugs reduced if we engaged in far more effective preventative health care. As Senator Puplick has already pointed out, the recent Australian Science and Technology Council report draws attention to the poor showing of Australia in respect of research and the application of that research.

This Legislative Research Service paper goes on to point out that there are difficulties facing the Parliament and any government in looking at cost effectiveness in these other areas. It states that, while the cost of drugs can be located precisely in government budgets, the cost of a thorough preventative health strategy would be spread through numerous portfolios and that the Government presently spends only $45m on health promotion and disease prevention. When one looks at that $100m in the area of anti-hypertensives and anti-hyperlipidaemics, the cost of $45m for preventative health care is seen to be relatively small. One might reasonably presage the results of a thorough review and suggest that they would indicate that the cost could be reduced through that mechanism.

Of course, this function has been entered into by pharmacists at no cost to the Government. In recent times pharmacists have been preparing a number of excellent, brief pamphlets, which they are making available to patients, on such things as diet, salt intake, sugar in the diet and exercise. Those pamphlets have been made available to their clients at no cost either to the client or to the Government. They have entered into this function because they see it as desirable. It is a function which could well be picked up and supported by government, but at this stage the Government seems far more intent on reducing the cost to the PBS merely by quite arbitrarily and wrongly attempting to take the costs from the hides of pharmacists around Australia.

Senator Puplick also mentioned that part of the increase in costs was due to the increased age of the population. The report to which I have been referring also mentions that fact, although it draws attention to the fact that that part of the increase is not substantial. Whilst we have an ageing population, we also have a smaller number of young people entering their earlier years of life, and the costs to government of all the services provided to those young people between the ages of 0 and 15 are less than the costs of providing services to the elderly. Of course, the Government is making substantial savings in those areas, particularly in the area of education, and I think that needs to be borne in mind. The facts show that, over the next 30 years, the dependency ratio in Australia-that is, the ratio between the numbers of people working, earning and paying taxes and those who are dependent upon them-will be lower than at any time since 1947. So the Government cannot hide behind the claim that the ageing of the population is a major factor in pushing up the PBS. In the few seconds left to me I again return to the point that the pharmaceutical benefits--

The Government likes to say, in a high-minded manner, that the underlying principles for the administration of and access to drugs by the Australian community are to enable a public subsidisation of the delivery of the most reliable and modern pharmaceuticals at affordable prices with maximum assistance going to those in greatest need and that those principles, which have been in effect for 40 years, are just as sound now as they were when they were first instituted. But what has happened is that the cost of administering the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) has gone up simply because the cost of new drugs has gone up and this Government is trying to make the pharmacists wear the cutbacks.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known in this country that, during that 40-year period, the PBS has delivered to the Australian people cheaper drugs than can be obtained in the rest of the world. Indeed, in one way, the purchasing policy of the PBS, which determines the cost of drugs in this country, prevents the pharmaceutical industry in Australia from becoming an export competing industry because of the manner in which international prices are set. But the cost of the delivery of pharmaceuticals and devices to the ordinary Australian consumer is about to be increased again as the therapeutic goods Bill will soon be introduced into this chamber. The therapeutic goods Bill will impose upon both the pharmaceutical industry and the devices industry a further impost whereby they will be required to pay a set fee, to be set by regulations, which fee is to be a cost recovery exercise, which some people say amounts to a tax. No doubt it will be subject to a challenge, but it will be an additional impost which will be borne by the pharmaceutical companies, and such cost will undoubtedly be passed on to the consumer.

At present we have a system whereby the Government determines the cost of the drugs. It allows the wholesalers a mark-up, which used to be 15 per cent but which is now 10 per cent, and the Government determines that it is stuck at 10 per cent. The wholesalers are allowed to make up that 5 per cent that has been cut back by Government action by putting a surcharge on to the wholesale cost to the individual pharmacists if the pharmacists do not choose to buy the product in what one might describe as job lots or in the manner in which the manufacturer supplies the commodity to the wholesaler. But the Government does not allow the individual pharmacist the same right to surcharge where he or she cannot recover any additional handling charges that may be incurred simply because the Government has the power to arbitrarily say, `This is what you are permitted to do and this is what you are not permitted to do'.

So, on top of that, the Government now says to the pharmacists, `No longer will we recognise your professional skills and your ability to counsel and to give advice outside the actual dispensing of pills and potions; no longer will you be paid a professional fee of $2.64. Instead, we will merge the professional fee and the handling fee, which was hitherto 25 per cent of the given list price-the given list price not including the surcharge which may be payable on drugs which chemists choose to order in smaller amounts than the manufacturers' package of 10 or a dozen'. So the net result is a downgrading of the pharmacists' skills and professional recognition. It is a downgrading of the fee they are paid to handle stock that they keep and maintain at cost to themselves in this climate of high interest rates-which has been deliberately brought about by actions of this Government. Small business men and women in Australia are now having to meet interest rates of 25 per cent. That is the level of interest rates that Mr Keating said at the Metal Trades Industry Association dinner the other night might come about some day. But people are paying that now. With chemists having to meet that sort of interest bill, and with the Government at the same time saying that they may not in any way seek to alleviate those imposts by having a surcharge and that it will cut back the handling fee that it arbitrarily said that they may have, we find that they are being squeezed at both ends.

It is quite clearly a deliberate policy, firstly, to make pharmacists wear the blame for the increasing cost of the PBS and, secondly, implement a policy which will simply force many of them out of business. The Government's policy is simply to say to pharmacists that with the same amount of money and more work they may be able to keep body and soul together. The Government is entering into a scaremongering campaign, trying to frighten people into believing that they will be unable to have drugs that they would ordinarily expect the chemist to dispense, yet it is the Government's own policy that is forcing this plight on Australian citizens. How on earth can the Government expect chemists, who probably have a mortgage on the premises where the business is conducted or, alternatively, pay high rental, to maintain expensive and costly stock lists and pay interest rates of 25 per cent?

No consideration is given by the Government to the economic plight it has brought about overall, yet it is singling out pharmacists to wear the heat and the blame. Is it any surprise that thousands of them have bothered to congregate here to try to have their will heard by the government of the day? The reality is that the government of the next day, the coalition government, will listen to what they have to say. The Government's rendition will be given when the next election is held, judgment made about its competence and it is voted out of office.
