If any honourable senator can establish from that press release that an agreement was made, he is a better man than I am. There was never any agreement. What was referred to was the agreement that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claimed that he made with the pharmacists. There was never any agreement made with the pharmacists and the Government reneged on its decision to postpone the actual reduction of the mark-up by a month.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done to the press gallery? Just look at it.

—I am not concerned about the press gallery; my concern today is that every pharmacist in Australia will be listening to this debate, and the hypocrisy of the Government will be exposed. The people are dedicated to remove the Labor Government from office, as they rightly should be.

SPEECH.PARA: I was advised only the other day that Tasmanian pharmacists are running a very good commercial in Tasmania. It is absolutely correct. It shows a pharmacist shutting his shop at 5 o'clock at night. A lady comes along wanting assistance. The chemist sits her down and tries to help her. The next picture shows the Prime Minister talking to a pensioner and saying, `You silly old bugger'. That is what it is all about. That is what this Government thinks of the pensioners of Australia. Then it tries to discredit the pharmacists and remove their credibility by spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on pamphlets and advertising in national magazines. That is absolutely disgraceful.

The pharmacists today are facing an average loss of up to $27,000 each. Many pharmacists will not be able to sustain that loss of revenue. Very few pharmacists will be able to keep their doors open. Probably one-third of Australian pharmacies will go out of business. In Queensland, 82 towns and communities have only one pharmacy and many of them will be placed at risk. The Government does not seem to care about that. It comes up with some half baked idea on how it will be able to sustain pharmacies in one town, but it will be an arbitrary decision; it will depend on the good wishes of the Government. When that happens, many towns will be left without a pharmacy.

All businesses in Australia have the right to mark up the price of a product. The Government does not understand the basics of business. It is impossible to buy a product and then sell it at the same price. Many pharmacists carry stock worth around $70,000 to $80,000. They then have to pay interest rates of 23 per cent to 25 per cent, again inflicted on them by this uncaring Government, which says it knows what small business is all about. It is impossible to survive with a revenue loss of $27,000 and then have to pay interest rates of 23 per cent to 25 per cent. It just cannot be done. Yet no-one in the Government has addressed that problem.

The Government will send more small businesses to the wall. In the year in which the Liberal-National Party Government left office, 1982-83, there were 6,035 small business bankruptcies. Three year later, in 1987-88, bankruptcies had gone up by one-third. That is this Government's sorry record-a one-third increase in bankruptcies. Senator Richardson has been attempting to interject. I will not be diverted. The Government's decision on pharmacies will increase last year's figure of 9,421 bankruptcies. That is the record the Government says it is proud of.

The brochure put out by the Labor Party entitled The Truth and Nothing but the Truth about the Cost and Supply of Prescription Medicines is absolutely disgraceful, dishonest and misleading. It is designed to remove the pharmacists' credibility. As the pharmacists know, and as the Government's research has proved, the pharmacists have a high credibility level. The Government's research shows that, for it to win this argument, it has to indulge in some grubby little scheme and get out there and spend hundreds of thousands of taxpayers' dollars on a carefully orchestrated move to discredit the pharmacists. The Government is not succeeding; it is not winning. In three months time, or whenever the Government decides to call a Federal election, not only the pharmacists but the whole small business community will be in full attack because they know that what the Government is doing to the pharmacists is a forerunner of what it will do to the small business community-that is, the ones that have survived six years of the Government's shocking mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating some amendments that the Senate made to the National Health Amendment Bill a couple of weeks ago in which we sought to restore the status quo with regard to the remuneration of pharmacists. Since that time we have had a lot of heat and probably very little light in the debate. People do not seem to understand the nature of the industry and how it works. If one thinks about it in relatively simple terms, one realises that it is the doctors who prescribe the drugs. The amount of money spent on medication is primarily determined by doctors, not by pharmacists. To attempt to come in at that end to save money, as the Government is attempting to do, is really to misunderstand the procedures that have over a very long time been developed in the pharmacy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Some extraordinary statements have been made today. For example, there was the statement that in the last six years 200 additional pharmacies have been established. I am not quite sure where that honourable senator has been for the last six years, but in Brisbane alone over 60 new suburbs have been established; and more than 220 communities have been established in the rest of the country. A pharmacy is an essential element in each community. We have come to expect it; we have come to demand it. On the basis of reasonable health delivery, that is good.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many, Senator?

—The honourable senator asks how many. It is important to look at where we are in world terms. Let us compare ourselves to the United States of America and Britain to see how prescription prices compare to average weekly wages. That is a reasonable comparison. We like to compare ourselves to those types of countries. In Australia, prescription prices as a percentage of average weekly earnings are 1.8; in the United States they are 4.3; and in Britain they are 4.2. Our pharmacies in world terms are highly efficient and are doing very well on very little. They are providing a tremendous service for a much lower remuneration than their counterparts in other countries. Indeed, in Australia in 1955 the figure was 6.6 per cent; we are now down to 1.8 per cent. So before we start denigrating an entire industry, as is happening in this debate, we should see precisely what the industry is doing and how it is providing a service to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some talk about the need for rationalisation. Probably in any industry there is need for rationalisation over time. I certainly accept that. But, indeed, as honourable senators know-or hopefully know if they have paid attention to the range of debates we have had in this country when we have restructured industries-we have not attempted to restructure industries by driving people into bankruptcy. We have sought to restructure industry in such a way that small businessmen could leave that industry with their assets intact so that they could start up again.

Unfortunately, the structure that the Government is attempting to impose on pharmacies with this draconian legislation will target the older pharmacies. The stability of ownership of pharmacies in this country is quite remarkable. What we are doing-probably unbeknown to people in the bureaucracy, who do not seem to understand the way the system has been structured over a number of years-is targeting the pharmacies that have been in existence for 30 to 40 years. They are the inner city pharmacies, which have tended to be in locations not accessible to cars because they are not able to pull up outside the pharmacies. Newer pharmacies have tended to locate themselves in places such as major shopping centres and the like where there is parking. Older pharmacies have not done this, and they will be the first to go to the wall. It is those pharmacists, often over the age of 50 and with their entire life savings in those pharmacies, who in reality are the people who will be hurt. It is not just a conglomerate out there; it is not just a pharmacy industry; it is people's lives and the people who will be hurt are the people who have given marvellous service to this community over many years. They are the pharmacies that will first go to the wall; not the ones in convenient locations and at better access points.

It is very difficult to know where to start in this exercise because there have been so many distortions. The 25 per cent mark-up is not a 25 per cent mark-up; it is probably more like a 20 per cent mark-up. The reason for that is that the shelf pack discount that is sometimes waved at by the Government and certainly by the Minister, as though it applies to every item, does not apply to every item. Indeed, I will give an example. There are a number of gels of which the average stock for a pharmacist is one a month. There is no discount on that. The wholesalers are responding to the squeeze and lowering their mark-up by 33 per cent. Again, the squeeze comes through from the Government on the wholesalers, who then pass it on to the retailers. But the retailers have nowhere to pass it on to. So the 25 per cent mark-up is much more like a 20 per cent mark-up.

There are so many other things that the Government seems to have neglected. For example, let us look at some of the primary health care inquiries that have been made in Australia. I have figures from a previous inquiry which are four or five years old and need to be updated but which constitute the most recent authoritative information I have been able to get. In 1985, 44 million primary health care inquiries were made of pharmacists compared with 29 million general practitioner consultations. Considering the Medicare arrangements in this country, if the 44 million primary health care inquiries had to be paid for because people wanted to see a doctor, it is obvious that this country could not afford it.

The professional input of pharmacists to the community has been enormous, and not only in terms of their care of the community. That is acknowledged by the community in a way in which it does not acknowledge our jobs, for example. Every year, the pharmacists are at the top of the list of people to whom the community looks up. That has been achieved by long and meritorious service to the community. It could not have been achieved by a group of people seeking to rip off the community, as a number of Government spokesmen have said, and they know it. The only way to get such a rating from the community is to do a job and do it very well. That high standing is grudgingly earned. A standing of 80 per cent is good in any terms, particularly as politicians rate about 12 per cent. That standing is well earned.

Computerisation has not been mentioned in this debate. Australia has moved, ahead of the rest of the world, to computerised dispensing, at no cost to the community. No other country has reached the level we have. This has been done solely at the cost of the pharmacists. Why do I mention this? The Government has agreed to pay pharmacists on computers within 10 days of the lodgment of their monthly claims, whereas non-computerised pharmacists' claims will take up to 30 days. Of course, it now takes about 90 days, if it manages to come through at all. The average saving to government of that exercise, financed by the pharmacists themselves, is conservatively put at $20m a year. That is another area where the pharmacists have sought to provide a service.

We could go on to look at the rates the Government pays its own pharmacists on contract. That is about $40 an hour compared with the rates currently being paid in the largest State, New South Wales-somewhere between $11 and $20 an hour. At the end of the day the Government is talking about dollars. The difficulty is that our community is changing. For example, we know that in 1986-87 about 60 per cent of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme went to pensioners. That figure is now 70 per cent. Demographic changes in our community will increase the costs. Unless we can actually slow down the ageing process, costs will increase in that area. That has to be recognised and accepted. The structures have to be reorganised.

The pharmaceutical benefits scheme as a percentage of the total health bill-I think it is a reasonable exercise to consider this, in view of what the Government is currently about-was 22.5 per cent in 1961, 14 per cent in 1975 and 8.4 per cent in 1986. In anyone's terms that would suggest a movement of costs away from pharmacists into other areas. Those movements may be legitimate but, whatever one wants to read into those figures, one cannot say that pharmacists have been on a money grabbing exercise.

When the Minister and others talk about the incomes of pharmacists and others, I wish they would tell us whether they are talking about gross or net income. I heard the Minister on the radio a couple of weeks ago carrying on at great length about the increased income of pharmacists. When I checked, I found he was talking about the gross income. Perhaps the Minister has not run a small business, but it is a pretty simple fact that can be readily grasped that one can have an enormous gross increase in income and still manage to go bankrupt. The reason is that there can be an even larger increase in costs. At the end of the day it is not what the gross income is; it is what is made out of the exercise as to whether one can stay in business. That amount has been dropping, not increasing. The fact that new pharmacies open does not mean that everyone is making a great killing on the exercise. Nor does it mean that every time a new dress shop opens everybody is making a killing in selling dresses. There is an enormous movement in costs which is nowhere near as great as the movement in income.

In this dispute with the pharmaceutical industry the Government has directed its attention towards a group of people who have provided very good service. Let us be clear about this: the Government was seeking $30m to give to the doctors to buy them off in their dispute, and it took the money from the pharmacists. Because of the way that budgets work, the money has to come out of the same budgetary arrangement. That is all very fine. It may have saved the Government's bacon with regard to the doctors, but not with regard to the pharmacists. Now is the time to go back to the status quo, sit down at the table and discuss all the types of rearrangements that are necessary to take the industry into the 1990s. Many are definitely needed.

The only sense one can make of Senator Boswell's comments is that it is still relevant for the Nationals to run their campaign in Queensland on the fear bogy of socialism. This has nothing to do with the discussion at hand. Then Senator Boswell went on to another very important point-that a number of towns in Queensland have only one pharmacy. Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it jurisdiction in relation to Qantas?

ANSWER.PARA: The other aspect-and I will close on this-is that if there is not a technical breach of the Act, and I would hope that there is not, the Government expects a reasonable standard of ethical behaviour, especially from major Australian corporations. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to current arrangements whereby Cambodia's seat at the United Nations General Assembly is occupied by a representative of the Coalition for Democratic Kampuchea, which includes the infamous Khmer Rouge. I also refer him to the recent withdrawal of Vietnamese military forces from Cambodia to which he referred in Question Time yesterday. Does the Minister not agree that the present situation is anomalous, given that the current occupants of the Cambodian seat are not truly representative of the people or the Government of Cambodia? In view of recent developments, will the Government move to refer the question of who should occupy the Cambodian seat to the Credentials Committee of the United Nations? Given the existing precedents, will the Government have its representatives in the United Nations General Assembly move to have the Cambodian seat declared vacant? Finally, is Australia's foreign policy on this question being unduly influenced by the position taken by the United States of America and members of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), particularly with respect to the role of the notorious Khmer Rouge faction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can add terribly much to what Senator Button said last week in answer to a question from Senator Vallentine on just this subject. But let me go through it, nonetheless. The Cambodia seat at the United Nations is held by so-called Democrat Kampuchea, the government of which is described as the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea or CGDK. CGDK comprises, of course, the Khmer Rouge, the Funcinpec group, so-called, led by Prince Sihanouk, and the KPNLF, or the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by Mr Son Sann. The head of the CGDK delegation at the United Nations is a member these days of the Khmer Rouge faction. Australia has never accepted the claims of the CGDK to be the government of Cambodia. Nor, for that matter, has it accepted the claims of the Phnom Penh regime-the People's Republic of Kampuchea-led by Hun Sen to be the government of Cambodia. We have stayed aside from the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: For the issue of CGDK credentials to be considered by the General Assembly Credentials Committee, there has to be a formal challenge. There has been no such challenge since 1982 and on that occasion Australia abstained, reflecting the position that I have just described. There are no indications that a challenge will be mounted by anyone else at the current session of the UN General Assembly. In fact, the report of the Credentials Committee has already been accepted by the Assembly this year. Australia's present assessment is that if a challenge were to be mounted now or were some other procedure to be adopted to get the matter back before the Credentials Committee, that challenge would not be successful in view of the strong majority support which is presently continuing for the CGDK among the ASEAN countries, most Western countries and many developing countries.

In any event, we take the view that the Cambodia conflict is not simply going to be resolved by a vote as to who is entitled to hold the Cambodia seat at the United Nations. I think the question of seating is seen these days by pretty much everyone as a secondary or subsidiary issue which will be relatively easily able to be resolved in the context of a larger settlement. I do not think it is seen by anyone, except some of the people who write to members of parliament about it, as being the key which will unlock the whole Cambodian conflict. If it were, it may be that more time and attention could sensibly be devoted to trying to build a new consensus for tackling the seat issue head-on and finding some way through it.

Australia's position, as I described it yesterday, is that a durable solution, as we see it, in the present environment can be achieved only by a comprehensive political settlement-one which, among other things, does establish an interim administration which would assume, under the kind of plan which is being talked about, Cambodia's seat, pending elections taking place. Another alternative variation to that plan is for the seat to remain vacant during the tenure of any such interim administration and pending elections. A number of other things are, of course, necessary in any such comprehensive settlement, one of which is the provision of the necessary safeguards to ensure that there is, of course, no return to the atrocities of the Pol Pot era.

All Australia's efforts are devoted to ensuring that there is a durable settlement which, at present, we believe can only be a comprehensive settlement-not a piecemeal one addressing part of the problem. That is the view that is taken by all the other ASEAN countries and the United Kingdom and France, which has been active in Paris-as well as the United States. I have to say that the United States has not played and is not playing a prominent or central role in any of the current or previous rounds of deliberations. It is present but it would be quite wrong to regard Australian policy-or for that matter anybody else's policy-as driven by United States perceptions at present. We do not want to take any action at all which would compromise any effort to achieve a durable solution, and we certainly do not want to settle for some kind of partial solution which would do no more than condemn the Cambodian people to another round of civil war and another round of killing. All our efforts are devoted to trying to avoid that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to a report that Ansett Airlines recently convened a meeting in Sydney of major tourist operators who were demanding to know the real facts about current travel capacity as opposed to the propaganda, both from the Government and from the airlines, which clearly does not accurately reflect the actual situation facing those wanting to travel by air. —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security seen reports of the Country Women's Association's (CWA) views on family assistance policies published recently? What implications do those comments have for the Government's policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen comments from a Mrs Tom, the National President of the Country Women's Association--
—Do you go to its meetings often?

—I am sure that it will not be inviting the honourable senator in the future-in what I am sure is quite a significant statement on social policy in this country. It is one that emphasises very strongly the need for a policy to target need in welfare expenditure. Mrs Tom is reported as attacking the Opposition's economic action package because it discriminates against families in need. The fundamental problem with the Opposition's policy-that it is not targeted-is the thrust of the attack. The question which I think honourable senators would be interested in is Mrs Tom's statement:

ANSWER.PARA: It seems more money will go to the more successful families and less money will go to the less successful families.
Just because children live in rural areas doesn't mean to say that they shouldn't have the same opportunities as city children.

This comment comes very much from the heartland of the constituency of members of the Opposition. It undermines the credibility of their package. It exposes its inequity and exposes it as a document born out of cynicism and opportunism and very much an uncaring document. It is quite apparent that the Opposition has replaced social policy planners with advertising agents.

It is quite curious that Senator Chaney is rolling over with laughter. I remind Senator Chaney that in the Senate on 8 September 1976 he had a much different view about this. He might be turning red now. He stated:
I believe it is terribly important that within that framework of financial restraint the Government has concentrated on looking after the needy.

That is one comment, but we can find others. What does the Country Women's Association want? Basically, it wants a package which provides extra assistance to families most in need and it recognises in its statement that rural families fit very much within that category. It is quite apparent as time goes by that the Country Women's Association is another group which has come up objecting to the Opposition's approach in this particular area.

It is also pertinent to compare the two approaches in terms of targeting the needs of people such as those in the constituency of the CWA. On the one hand we have a government which has had its policy driven from years of research and the Social Security Review. It is a policy which assists two million families with 3.8 million children. It is a policy which gives additional assistance to half a million families with 1.2 million children through family allowance supplement or its equivalents. There are five basic features of that policy which are fundamental to obtaining fairness and equity in the system. Under the Government's policy, firstly, assistance is paid to the mother fortnightly; secondly, it is fully indexed to maintain its real value; thirdly, it is targeted; fourthly, it is tax free; and, fifthly, and most fundamentally, it gives assistance to those most in need. It is very much a policy geared towards achieving fairness, equity and certainty. On the other hand, we are offered a tax rebate which, firstly, is not targeted; secondly, is not paid to the mother; thirdly, is not paid regularly; fourthly, is not indexed; fifthly, does nothing for those most in need; and, sixthly, and probably most fundamentally, the Australian community is asked to wait until September 1991 or thereabouts to achieve the benefits of it.

This Government has, for quite some time now, seen assistance to families as a priority that needs to be addressed systematically and with fairness and equity. In doing so, we will proceed to develop policies along those lines. We will not replace the social policy planners with advertising agents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on the Opposition's family policy because--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the Minister was not asked to comment; she was asked to answer two questions which are quite specific. Mr President, I ask you to call her to order and to answer the two questions.
—I call the Minister.

—I have been asked to answer two questions but, Mr President, I am sure that you will agree that there is a great deal of confusion in the electorate about precisely what the Opposition's child-care policy is. But it is possible for the question to be in order if it alludes to whether the Government is thinking of adopting those policies, whether it has costed those policies, et cetera. That is the distinction. Mr President, if it were simply a question going to what an Opposition policy was I would ask you to rule it out of order. However, if a question asks whether the Government is considering adopting a matter of policy, it is in order.
—Order! I ask Senator Reynolds to answer those questions that are within her area of responsibility.

—Senator Chaney asked specifically about targeting, child-care rebates and child rebates. It is quite clear that those on lower incomes will be the most disadvantaged. We are told that the Opposition is planning to introduce a child-care tax rebate which is worth $20. However, we do not know-and Senator Newman failed to give an undertaking on this in a debate I had with her last week-the amount of resources the Opposition will put into the child-care program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I can quote to the Minister what was said by Mr Oakes. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not taking up the second part of Senator Chaney's question. He asked me quite specifically whether the Government had a commitment to the children's services program and whether the Government would continue to put resources into public sector child-care. Certainly, the Government will continue to pay a great deal of attention to the needs of working women and to the needs of women at home who are entitled to have occasional child-care-something that the Opposition's child-care rebates do not address. We will continue to place a high priority on policies that have an important impact on Australian women. We are not going to an election, as the Opposition is, suddenly discovering that we had better put something together to attract the women's vote. ANSWER.PARA: On Friday three or four flimsy pieces of paper were faxed to me in Hobart indicating what the Opposition intends to do for Australian women. We have a comprehensive policy; we have comprehensive programs; we have introduced a range of initiatives with State governments; and we are totally committed to genuinely improving the opportunities, in all areas of life, for Australian women. Andrew Peacock has suddenly decided to announce a grab bag of promises. I ask Australian women, and I am sure that many of them will be listening: How could you trust Andrew Peacock? Who will dictate to Andrew Peacock? It will be John Stone, John Hewson and John Elliott. Are those three Johns committed to child-care? TALK.START.PARA: —You are out of touch, you know.

—Senator Hill is the one who is out of touch because he is deriding the views of the Country Women's Association. If I were him I would not lightly deride the views of the Country Women's Association.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Why is it necessary to have in place the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service? Has the Government paid attention to its cost effectiveness? Can the Minister quantify any savings made and indicate whether, as a result of any such savings, the quality of the service has been adversely affected? Were the companies involved made to provide their own inspection process which would no longer inspect for quality but for the purpose of meeting the hygiene requirements of importing countries, would this provide a cost reduction of approximately $10m in current funding of the service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked, firstly, to describe the relevance of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I think it is fairly self-evident that, as Australia is a major exporter of primary industry products, it depends on a quarantine and inspection service that guarantees the health and freedom from disease and contamination of our agricultural products. A quarantine and inspection service is necessary to intercept the exotic diseases that may come into Australia, because of the increase in trade and travel, and to protect a fragile environment in this part of the world.

ANSWER.PARA: We rely on clean, contamination-free products to succeed against world trade barriers; we have an enviable reputation for that. If an outbreak of foot and mouth disease were to occur in Australia it would cost about $1.2 billion in lost agricultural production. For example, we would lose about $2 billion in lost trade, and about 43,000 jobs would go. That is one graphic example of what the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service does to prevent this type of disease. But there are other areas of our primary industries-sheep, wheat, fruit, rice and so on-that it protects and it guarantees the health of our products.

Since we came to government we have made significant changes in the Quarantine and Inspection Service resulting in cost savings. We have reduced by about 30 per cent in real terms the budget allocated to it initially. The savings on meat inspection have been about $10.5m, on fruit and vegetables, $1.3m, and on general quarantine, $5.3m. I could go on with others. We have transformed the Service into a lean and efficient service without any loss of quality in terms of the work that it does. We have consulted with agricultural producers on the way through, to guarantee that that is so. There is an acceptance and a recognition that it is a good service.

If we were to cut $10m from the Service, I have to say that, given the reforms that we have undertaken, we would run a very real risk that the quality of the service that we now present would be reduced significantly and there would be a threat of exotic diseases and contamination coming into Australia which would threaten our standing as a world exporter. Assuming the cuts were to manpower, as seems likely, if they were to meat inspectors we would have, given the very delicate nature of the negotiations on reducing the number of meat inspectors that this Government has entered into, a real threat of industrial disputation in the abattoirs of Australia which would not help our reputation. If the cuts were in the area of quarantine, we would have overcrowding in existing quarantine facilities, long delays in processing quarantined animals in Australia and a substandard service. If the cuts were on the inspection side, it would open up the possibility of more disease.

I recognise the words that Senator Burns has used in his question as coming from the Liberals' Economic Action Plan, which threatens to cut $10m from the quarantine service. If that were to occur, the consequences that I have just described would become very real. If we look further at that policy, we see that, in addition to the proposal for cost cutting of that magnitude, it also proposes to change cost recovery from 60 per cent as at present back to 50 per cent. That would impose a further cost reduction of $13m, so the total cost reduction would be $23m. Given the description I have been able to provide the Senate with about the effect of a $10m cut, there is absolutely no doubt that, if the measures advocated in that Economic Action Plan were to be imposed on the Quarantine and Inspection Service, Australia's standing in the world as an agricultural exporter would be at risk, if not directly threatened, and the quality of life we enjoy with our environment would also be dramatically threatened. Given the responsible changes that this Government has made to quarantine, and the cost cuttings that we have been able to achieve in that area, to impose an extra $23m cut in this area would be absolutely disastrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister stand by the allegations made by him in the Senate yesterday, and on earlier occasions by Ministers Morris and Willis, that the major impediment to pilots returning to work is intimidation and harassment by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP)-allegations first made in August, repeated in September and again in the last few days? If he does stand by those allegations, why has the Government failed to take any action to deal with such intimidation by using the Trade Practices Act or the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act which were enacted only last year, or the criminal law, to prevent this behaviour?

—The question is unsoundly based because I did not make that allegation in the Senate yesterday. I said that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was obstructing-I do not know whether I actually used the word `obstructing'-its members from returning to work. That is what I said.
—They were not the words.
—I will sit down and let Senator Chaney use the words.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Minister has taken his seat and invited me to use the words that he used yesterday, they were:

QUESTION.PARA: The major impediment is not the alleged lack of a check and training organisation but rather the AFAP's active discouragement of its members from offering themselves for employment with the airlines. The Industrial Relations Commission on 10 October clearly indicated that the AFAP's whole attitude to the dispute had been one of inflexible confrontation with a rejection of the principles of the Industrial Relations Commission and the processes of conciliation and arbitration.
The key issue now is clearly the rebuilding of the domestic airlines system of Australia and this will take place regardless of the intimidation of the Federation.

It is in that context that I asked my question of the Minister, who was repeating allegations made by Willis the previous day, by Morris in August and September, by Abeles and by very many other people, that intimidation by the AFAP is preventing a return to work. I remind the Minister that the Government has the power to get an injunction under the Trade Practices Act to prevent any hindrance of interstate trade and commerce. I remind him of the provisions of the industrial relations legislation which he put through the Senate and which prevents such behaviour and I ask him why the Government has failed to take any action of the sort that the Opposition has consistently sought from the Government to prevent this intimidation, if that is what is occurring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin as I began a minute ago. In respect of the pilots strike and the incapacity to settle that dispute, it is the active discouragement by the AFAP that has prevented that settlement taking place. It is the active discouragement by the AFAP of its members returning to work that lies at the core of the problem.
—Prevent it!
—If Senator Chaney wants to misrepresent this question and say that I--
—You used the word `intimidation'.

—Senator Chaney couched his question in terms of why the pilots strike continues. I said yesterday, and I repeat today, that it is because of the active discouragement by the AFAP of its members from returning to work. Eight weeks into the dispute Senator Chaney professes to be a model industrial relations expert; yet only 21 per cent of the business community understand what he is on about and support it. Eight weeks after this dispute has begun, he now says, `Go to the Trade Practices Commission'. In so far as the question relates to harassment, the Government has had communications from some pilots referring to threats or intentions to threaten by the AFAP--
—Intention to threaten?
—Well, anticipation of threats by the AFAP against some of its members following their return to work, that is, those pilots who have returned to work.
—That is illegal.
—Yes.
—Do something about it!
—Senator Chaney should not get so excited. He should let me answer the question. I am clear what the question is and he will be clear what the answer is in a minute. These threats--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need personal abuse. These threats apparently include the sending of wreaths to pilots who have returned to work, abusive phone calls, surveillance of homes and harassment in briefing rooms. The Government has informed the pilots expressing those concerns at these tactics that it will not tolerate breaches of the law. The State and Federal police will pursue with vigour allegations that fall within their jurisdiction. I hope and am sure that the Opposition will join me in condemning the tactics of the AFAP in attempting to extend this dispute further by such behaviour.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, in a statement issued on 12 September, I referred to the suggestion we made on 23 August that the Trade Practices Act be used for this purpose. We repeated on 12 September that the Government should immediately seek an interlocutory injunction from the Federal Court of Australia to prevent the Federation from engaging in any conduct that hinders trade or commerce between the States. I point out that the Government has taken no action on this, and I ask the Minister why.

—Again we find the same confusion in Senator Chaney's head between the question of actively discouraging members from returning to work and the question of physical harassment and so on. They are two distinct questions. One relates to the use of the powers of the Trade Practices Act, which essentially relate to industrial relations. The second relates to the question he originally asked me about the Federation intimidating pilots. I have given an answer on that. That is a police matter and that is the way the Government will see that it is handled.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that a number of seats are presently vacant on international carriers operating between domestic air terminals? If so, is this due to the present booking system whereby Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines handle the bookings for the international carriers-a situation which makes it impossible for potential travellers to contact the international carriers themselves for domestic flights? Is the Minister aware of the great damage being done to the Australian economy, particularly the tourist industry, by the lack of easily obtainable air travel bookings? If he is, what steps will he take to ensure that all available international air carrier seats are utilised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that there are empty seats on some international carriers flying over domestic sectors. The bulk of those empty international seats are on services between Sydney and Melbourne, the route on which the majority of those international services operate. It also reflects the fact that Ansett and Australian are steadily increasing their own services on that route. On 20 October, for example, there were about 40 flights on that route. It is the case that passengers find it more convenient and time saving to travel between domestic terminals rather than through the international terminals when domestic flights are available on those particular routes. It is also true that many of the international services linking domestic capitals operate at inconvenient times of the day. That again is a disincentive to significant usage for domestic purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The domestic airlines are coordinating the bookings on the international airlines and on their own services to ensure that passengers are offered the fullest possible choice of times to travel. That is the reason and, so far as I am advised, the system is working perfectly sensibly. It has not been in itself a constraint to the effective utilisation of those international seats. It is the case that Ansett and Australian recognise the need to restore a full range of services across their networks as soon as possible. The airlines are presently working on schedules with additional capacity provided from their own and leased aircraft which will enable people to book with confidence over the Christmas holiday period and beyond.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE: IMPOSITION OF WORK BANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the Parliament of the nature and extent of industrial bans being imposed by unions in the Federal Public Service in pursuit of the unions' pay claims? In view of the fact that the Government supported the cancellation of the airline pilots' award within four days of the imposition of bans by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots in the current dispute, will the Government be taking similar action against Federal public sector unions? If not, what action does the Government propose to take in relation to these Public Service bans?

—The first cessation of work by public servants was on Monday of this week. Discussions are taking place about these matters in terms of the restructuring principles. If they are not resolved to the Government's satisfaction, the Government will determine what action has to be taken.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister say whether he is going to put a timetable on what is required as satisfactory progress in these discussions, and what action is then contemplated?

—I cannot do that, but I will ask the responsible Minister what progress has been made in relation to this matter. I will then advise Senator Bishop. When this issue occurred in certain sections of the Public Service two years ago the Government moved very rapidly on the question of stand-downs of employees and so on. That dispute was resolved. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and relates to the issue of pulp mills. If the Minister's Government is committed to environmentally sustainable development why, in both the review of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the Commonwealth draft new bleached eucalypt kraft pulp mill standards and guidelines report, was only the kraft chlorine method discussed at great length? Why has the Government not considered alternative bleach pulp mill methods such as the chemo-thermo-mechanical pulp and peroxide method and alternative raw materials for paper making? The Commonwealth's draft pulp mill guidelines appear to contradict the CSIRO's paper, which states that no answer is available or likely to be available in the foreseeable future to the question of what concentrations of toxic compounds from the kraft chlorine effluent are sufficient to cause a deleterious effect to aquatic organism, whereas the Commonwealth's draft pulp mill guidelines report states that the Commonwealth will be satisfied that the effluent will cause no acute short term adverse environmental impact and that any chronic long term adverse impacts will be identified before irreversible damage is probable. Can the Minister explain this discrepancy between the two reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be rude to Senator Vallentine, but imagine what anybody listening to that question on the radio would think. They would say, `What on earth is this gobbledegook all about? Who understands it except the person who wrote the question for Senator Vallentine?'. Let me say two things about this. The Government has under consideration draft guidelines for kraft pulp mills. I would not get agitated at this stage. The guidelines are being considered by the Commonwealth Government and by State governments. They are being exposed to environmental groups for consideration and so on. They are drafts. We will resolve these issues and a final set of guidelines will be produced, as the Government undertook when it set this process in train.

ANSWER.PARA: The second observation I want to make is that it is quite implicit in Senator Vallentine's question that she does not understand the expression `environmentally sustainable development'. She does not understand what that means. It does not mean that any industry which has any effect on the environment at all is not a sustainable development. Sustainable development means sustainable development which has no long term deleterious effects on the environment in proportion to all the other effects on the environment from all sorts of human behaviour in various areas of human activity. It is a matter of arriving at a balanced view about these things. The question clearly implies that Senator Vallentine does not understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 October Senator Vallentine asked Senator Robert Ray as Minister representing the Minister for Defence a question about the deployment of Defence Force personnel to the joint defence facility at Nurrungar. TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 October, Senator Panizza asked me a series of questions relating to the crew of the Royal Brunei Boeing 757 aircraft. The burden of those questions related to whether the pilots of that airline were flying longer hours than prescribed.
—It was a question that Senator Collins answered in the Estimates committee.

—Perhaps the question should not have been asked again; I do not know. In essence, the answer is that the airline is complying with Australian provisions. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
In Question Time on 6 October 1989 Senator Panizza asked me the following questions:
Q. Is it a fact that the crew of the Royal Brunei 757 Boeing aircraft, currently chartered for use internally in Australia, operated a period of 14 hours 40 minutes duty time one day last week?
A. No. In the week 24-30 September 1989 Royal Brunei company records show that the longest overall duty period of any flight crew member was 12 hours and 45 minutes.

Q. Is it also a fact that the Captain and crew elected to take only a nine hour rest period before resuming flying next day because they are operating under British CAA regulations which permit both this and the former action?
A. No. The minimum rest period after the 12 hours 45 period of duty specified in the Royal Brunei Operations Manual is 12 hours and 45 minutes, which was observed in this case.

Q. Is the Minister aware that under Australian CAA regulations a maximum period of only 11 hours rostered duty is allowed, which may be extended to 12 hours but that where this is done a subsequent mandatory rest period of 24 hours must be observed?

A. This is incorrect. Following a 12 hour tour of duty, the Civil Aviation Orders require a pilot to have a rest period of 13 hours or 14 hours, depending on whether the tour of duty was completed before or after 10 p.m. The rest period of 24 hours is only required when the tour of duty exceeds 12 hours.
Q. Is the safety of the Australian travelling public being put at risk by having different safety rules for the same task or situation?

A. No. Foreign aircraft presently operating over Australian domestic sectors are required to demonstrate compliance with internationally accepted standards in precisely the same manner as existed before the dispute. While in some cases these standards may differ from those normally applicable to Australian domestic operations, there is no suggestion that these standards are in any way less safe when examined in the context of the foreign Authority's entire regulatory structure and certification requirements.

Nevertheless, in the interests of uniformity, the CAA has requested foreign operators who wish to conduct operations in Australia for a protracted period to demonstrate closer compliance with Australian regulatory requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Stone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's policy to deal with the fundamental problems of the economy as reflected in the further downgrading of our international credit rating and the continuing crisis in the balance of payments and foreign debt situation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has just been read to the Senate is of particular aptness today in the light of the decision by the international credit rating agency, Standard and Poor's Corporation, and the September balance of payments figures, which were referred to during Question Time. It is also apt in the light of the further revision of the foreign debt figures and the foreign international investment position of Australia, also issued by the Australian Statistician today. Today the international rating agency, Standard and Poor's, said-I quote from the Reuters report from New York:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the weakened external position-
that is, of the country-
raises the country's vulnerability to adverse international economic developments and hampers policy flexibility.
The report went on to say:
Australia's net external debt rose to 200 pct of total exports in June. S/P said a rapidly growing private-sector borrowing more than offset lower Commonwealth external debt.
Further, the report said:
. . . the rating agency said Australia's growing foreign interest payments will slow the process of stabilising the external debt burden.

It added that the recent external imbalance occurred despite a sizeable increase in the terms of trade. You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), back in 1985, 1986 and early 1987, blamed all of this country's problems, all the great difficulties that the Government was contending with in stabilising what was then thought to be a very large balance of payments deficit, on the adverse movement of the terms of trade-a term of art used by economists. For the last two years, the Treasurer has been saying that the even further adverse movement in our external balance of payments has been because of the improvement in the terms of trade. I do not have time to spend on that further inconsistency of our shameless Treasurer.
What did our Treasurer, Mr Keating, say last night when the announcement by Standard and Poor's was received from New York? The Treasurer, in his press release issued last night, said:
U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's today changed Australia's long-term rating. . .

He did not even have the courage to say `downgraded' Australia's credit rating. He said `changed'-the kind of weasel word we are accustomed to from this Treasurer and this Government. With the abrasiveness which characterises every statement these days, the Treasurer then said:
This was not an unexpected development given the alternative ratings agency Moodys had already adjusted Australia's rating in August.

Although the Government totally rejects the need to downgrade Australia's rating it can understand that Standard and Poor's had little alternative given their competitor, Moodys, had already done so two months earlier.

I repeat: this is a Treasurer without shame. This morning what Paul Keating said on this matter a few months ago, at the time when Moody's Investors Service was announcing its downgrading of Australia's international credit rating, was replayed on the AM program. I express my gratitude to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for once. At the time the Treasurer said:
Standard and Poor's, on their record, have been a more professional organisation.
That is, more professional than Moody's. He continued:
They don't go in for these publicity stunts . . .
He concluded by saying:
But the point is, I think they're a more professional body.
The introducer of the program, Mr Peter Thompson, said:
Paul Keating, singing the praises of the international credit rating agency Standard and Poor's a few months ago.

That is the agency about which Mr Keating had the impertinence to say last night that its decision to downgrade our credit rating was not an unexpected development because of what its competitor, Moody's, had done a few months ago. This is the totally professional body which can do no more now, in the Treasurer's eyes, three months later, than simply follow its leader.
We had an answer to the Treasurer's words by the representative of Standard and Poor's, Mr Chambers, who, when the Treasurer's remarks of last night were put to him, said:
The competitive position-
that is, the competitive position vis-a-vis Moody's-
really doesn't enter into the discussion and the decision at all.
He went on to say:
We see no problem at all in having different ratings and really, we don't consider that at all in terms of whether we should make a rating change or not.

Here we have Standard and Poor's, this totally professional body according to the Treasurer three months ago, saying in as plain words as one can find that the Treasurer speaks with two tongues and that last night he was speaking with a tongue with which this agency totally disagrees.

We have a Treasurer without shame-a man who, in the House of Representatives debate yesterday, made some comment about this Labor Government having built the Empire State Building and the Opposition coming along, putting another brick on top and saying, `Look what we've done'. I continue to be astounded by the gall and effrontery of Mr Keating, but that was a bit rich even by his standards. To talk about digging a $108 billion hole of foreign debt and saying that that is building the Empire State Building, even by Mr Keating's standards, is an extremely rich proposition to be trying to put to the Australian public. I predict that this is a proposition that the Treasurer will not succeed in putting to the Australian public. The fact is that Mr Keating and his Government are still digging. As I said, they have dug a $108 billion hole, of which there was $23 billion to start with, I say to be fair. They have increased it by $85 billion in the last six and a bit years. But they are still digging, as today's release by the Statistician of the balance of payments figures for September illustrates.
During Question Time today I put a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who I am glad to see is still here. This will improve his education.

TALK.START.PARA: —He needs it.

—As Senator Boswell said, that will be very necessary. Today I put a question to Senator Button about these balance of payments figures. I remind him and his few colleagues opposite of some of the numbers. The September balance of payments figures, in unadjusted terms, show a deficit of $1,776m. That is for one month alone. The September seasonally adjusted figure that the Statistician now produces was $2,016m-just over $2 billion for one month of the year. As I said in my question to Senator Button earlier today, that means that for the first three months of this financial year-the July to September quarter-we have racked up a seasonally adjusted deficit in all of $5,819m-$5.8 billion. Since these are seasonally adjusted figures, this is equivalent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $23.3 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: If one does not like the figures on the three-month basis one can add the month of June, which also happens to be in the Statistician's release. Doing the same kind of calculations one finds that over the last four months the seasonally adjusted annual rate of the deficit is $22.8 billion. It is a little bit less but it is much the same. We are looking at a balance of payments deficit of about $23 billion, or if one wants to be generous to the Government, $22 1/2 billion-in other words, a blow-out. By comparison there is the extraordinary estimate of $18 1/2 billion put forward by the Treasurer in the Budget Papers. This is a repeat of what happened at the same time last year when, I remind the Senate, the Treasurer forecast a balance of payments deficit of $9 1/2 billion. We finished up with a figure which has been further revised upwards only today by another $180m and is now just in excess of $18 billion for 1988-89. That was the degree of blow-out last year. We are already developing a blow-out again-although of not quite a similar percentage size-this year.

Month after month during the last financial year the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is not here today, unfortunately-and I regret that he is ill-stood in this place and tried to defend the Government's balance of payments forecast and tried to justify the fact that no revision was being made. Then gradually revisions were leaked to the press and there was a further edging up of the figures, but at no time during the whole of last year did the Minister for Finance, representing the Treasurer, ever find himself in a position to be able to defend the forecast; and I predict that he will not be able to do so this year either.

In his response to me today, Senator Button tried to suggest that the answer to the problem concerning these figures was to be found in the fact that the Treasurer had stated in the Budget that the balance of payments would be weaker in the first half of the year than in the second half. As I said in my supplementary question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), although he did not choose to deal with it, on the basis of that arithmetic-if that is the rationalisation in which the Minister is putting his faith-it is a claim that, somehow or other, in the second half of this financial year there will be a balance of payments deficit running at only around $7 billion per annum, seasonally adjusted. All I can say is that, if we were to see a balance of payments deficit running at around only a $7 billion seasonally adjusted annual rate-which is just over $1 billion a month compared with the present $2 billion-that could come about only because the bottom had fallen out of the economy. It could come about only because of the recession which this Government has shied away from admitting it has actually forecast in the Budget Papers and which it keeps saying the Opposition will achieve through its policies. That is the implication of the Minister's defence during Question Time today. Whether or not he is aware of it is another question. No doubt he has not done his arithmetic. I have just done it for him and I hope that, at some future time, he will find some means of responding to this point.

As I said before, not only has the balance of payments figure been issued today, but also a revised figure-not very much revised, I should say-for debt for the period ended June this year; indeed, not just debt, but what the Statistician these days terms Australia's net international investment position. At 30 June last year it amounted to net-and I emphasise that word-foreign liabilities of $142.7 billion, which was an increase within the June quarter alone of $4.6 billion. Within that total figure of $142.7 billion is a net foreign debt figure-as distinct from the other forms of net liabilities-of $108 billion.

The wording of the matter of public importance we are discussing today speaks of the failure of the Government's policy to deal with the fundamental problems of the economy, as reflected in these matters I have been speaking about. The fact is that this disastrous balance of payments deficit, our extraordinary international debt and, indeed, our net foreign liabilities position are merely symptoms of what is wrong in Australia today. It is the lack of any policies on the part of the Government to deal with the fundamental problems which is producing these outcomes. Frankly, we have a non-competitive economy; an economy which is simply not hacking its way in the world; an economy in which the growth of productivity has been basically stalled for the last three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many years?

—It has been stalled, basically, for the last six years but the Government had a bit of productivity increase in the pickup from the drought-affected and international downturn situation which it inherited. It had a bit of a pickup at the beginning and has been stalled since. Money wage increases are going on apace. We cannot get real wage increases going on apace because the only way to do that-this is for Senator Button's benefit-is through productivity increases. We have not been getting any of those, least of all in the Commonwealth Public Service, over which this Government presides. Australia has a Third World air service at the present time, if that.
—We have no air service.

—My colleagues point out that I am being generous and I defer to their correction. It has been reported, and certainly not denied by the Government, that Sir Peter Abeles, the head of Ansett Airlines of Australia, has conceded to the tourist industry of this country that the airlines will not be back in full service before Easter of next year, at the earliest. That is the kind of service Australia is getting from the airline industry in this country, while the tourist industry goes down in a screaming heap.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a continuing shambles on the waterfront, with $150m of taxpayers' money being allocated to pay golden handshakes averaging $100,000 each, to 3,000 waterside workers in return for having sat on their backsides for the whole of their lives. The Government has done nothing in the coastal shipping situation. The Government is unable and unwilling-because the Public Service unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions will not let it-to tackle the gross problem of the need to privatise government business enterprises in order to give them, among other things, a chance to be more efficient and to provide a better working environment for their own employees, and more job satisfaction in the process. The tax burden for 1989-90 is still at a record level. More than half of our taxpayers are now paying over 40c in the marginal dollar of their incomes in tax. I am sorry to see the Minister leaving; I am sorry if he cannot take it, but there we are.

Inflation is mounting. It is 7.6 per cent in the 12 months to June. There is another consumer price index figure for the September quarter coming out tomorrow. I do not know what that figure will reveal, and I am not making any predictions, but I would be very surprised if it in any way significantly reduces that figure of 7.6 per cent, for the 12 months ended in September. In other words, the inflation rate is stuck between 7 per cent and 8 per cent.

What is this Government's policy to deal with these matters? Its only policy, which it has been following now in a manic manner since April of last year-18 months ago-is to put up interest rates higher and higher. It is true the Treasurer has done a sleazy deal with the four major banks to put a cap on bank mortgage loan rates, but all that means is that other people in the community will have to pay higher interest rates for longer. That is all it can mean. There is no free lunch in this area, as the Treasurer used to tell us. We have had nothing at all from the Government. By contrast, the Opposition has an Economic Action Plan which was brought down by the Leader of the Opposition nearly a fortnight ago and to which the Government has made no response. All we have had from this failed Treasurer, this man without shame, has been-if I may adapt a smart phrase of his of a few months back-what could be described as all lather, all heat. There has been no substance at all. In other words, we have had two wasted years from this Government since the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven wasted years.

—I agree, but since the last election it has been two wasted years. Where do we go from here? Let us assume that this Government carries on in the way it has until May, or whenever the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is now talking about for an election date. That means that by the middle of June next year Australia will have an economy in which demand has been savagely deflated; in which the growth of production will be at a halt, at best, if it is not actually falling; in which inflation will still be running at around 7 per cent to 8 per cent; in which the balance of payments figure will still be running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of probably $12 billion to $15 billion, not Senator Button's ridiculous implicit $7 billion; and in which foreign debt will be coming out of our ears even faster than it is today. Having arrived at that point, what then? Where do we go from here if demand is to be cranked up? Or is the Government to be content with that situation of total stagflation? The fact is that this Government has no answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we are having a general economic debate this afternoon. The thing that has always struck me is the enormous dichotomy between what is promised by the Opposition and what is delivered. That dichotomy was most revealed to me over the weekend when I was listening to a news program and Mr John Elliott, the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia, was getting fairly excited. One of the things that he said was, `What we are about is taking it off the bludgers and giving it to the workers'. Mr John Elliott, senior figure in the Liberal Party, its national President, its bagman for the next election, said that. When I picked up the Melbourne Age on Monday morning I found the same person has received a $10,000 a week pay rise-not $10,000 a year but $10,000 a week. I wonder at this dichotomy between what the Opposition promises and what it delivers. Here is the most senior figure in the Liberal Party next to Mr Peacock saying, `We will take it off the bludgers and give it to the workers'. Well, he certainly took it off someone-$10,000 a week-and we know whom he gave it to.

SPEECH.PARA: For a clear example of what the Mr Elliotts of the world bring about-not many people in this chamber would have had the privilege this year, but I did-people should go to Princes Park, Mr Elliott's football ground, the one he has redeveloped. If people want to see the two classes that someone like Mr Elliott will bring about, they should go to that ground and have a look at the $30,000 and $60,000 a year corporate boxes with people slurping away at four- and five-course meals, generally ignorant of football, as Senator Aulich would know, all by way of a tax deduction. Then people should look at the rest of the crowd stuck in the outer ground or in the wooden Gardiner Stand with the splinters, a fire trap. For people who wanted something to eat, one pie stall was provided by Mr Elliott's club for 15,000 people with a 150-yard queue going in one direction and another 150-yard queue in the other. At the end of the queue the pie stall happened to be selling export pies because ordinary ones had run out. That is Mr Elliott's vision. What is promised and what is delivered are absolutely entirely different.

I have to say that I am also disappointed with the role in politics played by the mover of this motion today over the last few months. No doubt Senator Stone has been described as a hard man and all the rest of it. But I acknowledge that he is an intellectual person and I acknowledge that he is a person of integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a caring senator.

—A caring person in terms of his staff; I also know that. But I believe that, if he has had a major role in developing the Opposition's economic package, he has gone to mush. He has gone through the metamorphosis from an economic rationalist to a carpetbagger. Far from taking the opportunity to make the Liberal Party tax policy set out some grand design to reshape the Australian economy, Senator Stone has participated in putting together the traditional grab bag of hand-outs and like all previous coalition fistful of dollars packages it was not adequately costed and cannot be funded from the savings measures described. We know there is a gross estimating error of about $835m. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot say, `We are going to take everyone off the dole after nine months but we will give them special benefits anyway'. Where is the saving there? When we look at the problems we should look at child-care. The Opposition's latest package now means that the $20 child-care rebate will become $11.70 and the $4.80 child tax rebate will become $2.80.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of this, over the last three days we have seen the development of the Opposition's child-care policy farce. Mr Connolly revealed the hidden agenda to the Sydney Morning Herald when he promised an end to the national child-care strategy with the axing of the Government's commitment to create an additional 30,000 publicly funded places. He also promised the discounting of fee relief for the rebate and the denial of access to publicly funded centres for all except those on very low incomes. On Monday Mr Connolly's leader dumped on him and said that he had just got it wrong about Liberal Party policy, that the Liberal Party would build the additional 30,000 places and it would not discount fee relief for the rebate. Mr Connolly's story was much more plausible. But Mr Peacock would not have any of the gloss knocked off his Economic Action Plan.

This morning we have another Opposition frontbencher, Mr Braithwaite, making another child-care promise, saying that the coalition would extend fee relief to the private sector-a new promise and one which certainly was not stated in Mr Peacock's famed Economic Action Plan and was not incorporated in the costings. I think Mr Braithwaite should be in the Australian Democrats. He expects us to believe that we can extend the fee relief to a whole class of people who do not already get it and that it will not cost anything. We are talking about subsidies of almost $80 a week and about $3,800 per child and it will not cost anything according to Mr Braithwaite. I admit that the Department of Finance has not costed it but I can tell the Opposition that it has the potential to cost a very significant amount of money. We have had three days of the Opposition making child-care policy on the run. Now Mr Peacock has a major problem of trying to salvage some integrity for his costings.

While we are on the subject of the lack of the Opposition's fiscal discipline, I think it is about time that Senator Stone demonstrated that he is performing the function of the shadow Minister for finance and stopped the shadow Minister for land transport and shipping support, Mr Sharp, putting out ridiculous press releases on road funding. Mr Sharp's press release of 23 September stated:

The Labor Government had made it plain that it does not take its responsibilities in roadworks seriously. By contrast, the Coalition is committed to a major increase in road funding-one that would permit the return of our road standards to those we used to take for granted as a right.

Honourable senators may wonder why, if the Opposition is committed to increased road funding, nothing was included in Mr Peacock's Economic Action Plan. Again, it is a case of the National Party of Australia, having accepted general parameters, trying to wag the coalition dog's tail. Out of this Economic Action Plan, firstly, we will get unfunded promises; secondly, the policy making and additional spending promises will be done on the run. We also have the Opposition's flawed fiscal policy which has left Dr Hewson with far less scope in which to manoeuvre on money and wages policies. In our view he would be forced to engineer a recession through higher interest rates to create the climate he needs for market deregulation--

TALK.START.PARA: —We won't have to engineer them; they will already be there.

—If Dr Hewson tried to deregulate the labour market without putting the economy into a recession, he would cause a wages explosion as surely as the coalition would have caused that wages explosion had it caved in to the pilots. I really wonder where the Opposition will go. I am not suggesting that the Opposition is in two factions. I wonder whether economic strength and rationality, even if it returns-and I hope it does-to Senator Stone, will prevail over the life of a coalition government or whether the Peacock pragmatists two years in will go to water as most Liberals go to water. Then we will see a replay of 1982 with a wages explosion, a recession, massive job loss for this country. I think the Opposition is just offering us a rerun of 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: In his mini-campaign Mr Peacock has raised hopes that he might have something else to offer with his proposals to adjust the tax treatment of interest for inflation. Yet it turns out that this has been yet another example of policy making on the run, of form without substance. The Treasury comprehensively demolished the tax treatment proposal. It was a partial proposal that would introduce new distortions into the tax system. It was too administratively complex. It had implications for Australia's international competitiveness for investment. Even Mr Brian Loton made reference to a certain South American country when he was asked about it. Mr Peacock's colleagues declined to offer him any support. In the end he dropped it.

Where is the coalition's alternative economic vision? Last week in the Australian we read that Dr Hewson had pushed for a consumption tax. We are told often that this is the panacea which will discourage spending and encourage savings. What happened to Dr Hewson's advocacy of a consumption tax? I think we all know the political reality and who intervened to put the fix in to belt that one out of the ring. I think everyone would also remember-no doubt it was said in a different context-Senator Stone's great comment, `Don't trust us on tax'. I do not think we can have any real trust in the Opposition on tax, especially when we look back this week at what has happened with Mr Braithwaite in regard to child-care and with Mr Connolly in regard to child-care places.

I want to mention one or two other things. It is not what was said today that is interesting. It is what is not being said. I raise this question and I invite Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Hamer to answer it. I want to know how the Opposition would fund the refund of bracket creep. We have had all the various one-liners. Let me remind honourable senators what was said on Channel 10's Face to Face program. Mr Peacock was asked:

Mr Peacock, I will go through this once more and then move on. Rain, hail, snow, no matter how big or how small the amount, you will be handing back to the Australian taxpayers the bracket creep that they lose in the year 1989-90?
Mr Peacock answered:
We will be doing that.

That is interesting. I ask Senator Stone, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Hamer: How would the Opposition fund that? Would it fund it out of the surplus? Why does the Opposition not come clean and tell us? How would it do it in successive years? Would it hand back all bracket creep? If so, how would the Opposition fund it? There is no mention in the Opposition's policy about how it would achieve that. That is a major problem. There is another major problem. The Opposition, in its economic policy, talks about privatisation and assets sales. I want to hear a commitment from Senator Stone or other honourable senators today regarding what the Opposition would do with the proceeds of those sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's in the policy; read it.
—The honourable senator says that it is in the policy. Would it be used to retire debt or would the Opposition, after a few months, go down the Thatcher road?
—You haven't read the words.
—It does not matter what is in the words. I am postulating where the Opposition would head with it.
—You are impugning our motives.

—Yes. Senator Sheil has woken up. Well done! I have spent 12 minutes impugning the Opposition's motives and Senator Sheil, with his perception, has finally discovered that. Well done, Senator! Welcome back. What happened in Thatcherite England is very interesting. The Government used the proceeds of privatisation and assets sales to fund its general programs. I wonder what the coalition would do the first time the pressure came on in Budget Cabinet if it were to win government-whether it would stick to its promise and use the proceeds to retire debt or whether it would use the proceeds to take the easy option.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something about the easy option. I have sat on this side of the chamber for a couple of years and listened to the toughies opposite.
