I have listened to Senator Hamer on how tough he would be with the wharfies and the shippers. I have listened to Senator MacGibbon on how tough he would be with the airline industry. I have heard all the bovver boys opposite tell us how tough they are gunna be. I think we are entitled to look at their track record. What did they ever do that was tough from 1975 to 1983? When did they ever take the tough option? When did they put up serious restructuring proposals? When, apart from one occasion-and I will come to it-did they ever get into the tax system? The only time they ever got into the tax system was in 1982, on bottom of the harbour tax-not out of principle but out of terror, the terror that hit them in late 1982 that unless they did something about bottom of the harbour tax they would be thrown out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —World parity pricing for oil.

—That was the one tough, gutsy policy-one. I will concede it to the honourable senator; I think it was an intelligent policy and I think it took some intestinal fortitude, but it was only one policy, basically. That is what the previous Government came up with. The coalition talks a tough fight, but look at its role in State government. Mr Greiner talked tough early on. He is becoming as weak as anything. He will not take on anyone. He gives in all over the place. So where is the credibility of the coalition? Honourable senators opposite talk a terribly tough fight-they are going to sort out this industry, and that union. What did they do with the Builders Labourers Federation from 1975 to 1983? They wrung their hands and they cried and they whinged. What did we do? We blew them out of New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory when that was necessary. We have taken a lot of the tough decisions. When we have taken the tough decisions where has the Opposition been? It has been in its bunker or it has indulged in carping criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go over a few examples that I recall. The most recent one was the gold tax. When we decided to introduce a gold tax, I think for very logical reasons-and we did it in a way which kept our previous commitments-we were rubbished in this chamber by honourable senators opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you make the previous commitment?

—We were rubbished by Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Panizza and told that it was totally wrong. We had taken a tough decision and when the going got tough those opposite squibbed. But now that all the dirty work is done and the tax is in place, the Opposition says it would go along with it and take the money.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there was the fringe benefits tax. Does Senator Aulich remember the months of criticism of the fringe benefits tax as we tried to get rid of the free lunch and the rest of the rorts in the system? The Liberals fought it like the Russians fighting in the Stalingrad tractor factory. They went back post by post and fought it. What are they going to do now? They say that they would keep it all. It is all okay now. All the hard work has been done. The bugs have been knocked out of the system. `We will take the $1,500m' say Senator Stone and Senator Sheil. `We will cop the dough, even though we opposed it in principle'.

The same thing happened with the assets test. Opposition senators went to water and would not have an assets test. Now they say they are going to take the money. The only one they would renege on is the biggie, the capital gains tax. If they ever come into this chamber and pass a Bill that reneges on capital gains tax it will be a tragedy for this country. It will erode our tax base and give enormous rewards to people who do not deserve them. We put a lot of thought into the capital gains tax and introduced it in such a way as to bring a lot of equity into the system. But no. They would get rid of it. The Opposition should have a good look at what the editorial of the Australian Financial Review said about this matter today because I think that for once, whilst I do not often read editorials or note their contents, it contained a fairly devastating criticism of the Opposition.

People listening to this debate should remember the dichotomy, the difference, between what the Opposition promises and how it postures when it acts tough, and the past reality. It has never had the courage to tackle the economy. In its Economic Action Plan it merely recast part of Government economic policy. It is a redistribution of income, and that is all. Where is all the Opposition's talk of its grand vision and of restructuring? It does not exist. The Opposition has no track record in this area. Senator Stone comes in here and attacks Mr Keating. Mr Keating is not perfect, but he will be remembered in this country for all the restructuring he has done, long after the Opposition is forgotten. He will be remembered as the Treasurer who first tackled Australia's long term problems. Those problems should have been tackled long before this Government came to power. I suggest they should have been tackled long before the Fraser Government came to power. On too many occasions political parties showed a lack of will and courage. I will always remember the visit of a French economist to Australia in 1968. He had a really good look at our economy. He said `Mr Ray, the Australian economy reminds me of the village idiot who wins the lottery every day of the week'. That is where we were in 1968. We are no longer winning the lottery. The hard things need to be done. This Government is willing to do those hard things. The credibility of the Opposition's promises is thin when we look at its record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are supposedly debating today is Senator Stone's motion relating to the fundamental problems of the economy reflected in particular in the further downgrading of our international credit rating and in the continuing crisis in our balance of payments and foreign debt situation. We have heard a lot, certainly from Senator Ray, about a great deal, but not much of it has been central to the topic that we are supposed to be debating. A lot has been said by both the previous speakers, Senator Stone and Senator Ray, on the minutiae of each other's policies but almost nothing has been said about what Standard and Poor's lists as the major cause of the problem, that is, our increasing foreign borrowings and the fact that private sector borrowings are increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to argue with Senator Ray's comments about how much the Australian Labor Party has done since it took office in 1983 to iron out some of the greater inequities in our tax system. After all, notwithstanding the furore, we were very much in support of a lot of those initiatives. I must say that I share the Government's cynicism when I read Mr Peacock's tax policy that essentially accepted a lot of the changes, with the exception of tinkering around with the capital gains tax, that the Opposition had opposed so vehemently in the past. I guess there is a certain irony in that the hard work has been done by others and has been accepted by critics. But I would not have thought that that is central to the debate that Senator Stone raised today. An article in yesterday's Age newspaper stated:
The influential Standard & Poor's credit rating agency . . . lowered Australia's long-term debt rating from AA-plus to AA.

It said the downgrading, which affects $10.4 billion in direct and guaranteed debt, reflects Australia's sharply higher current account deficit, prospects for protracted external adjustment, and increasingly heavy foreign debt burden.
But, importantly, it went on to say:

Australia's net external debt rose to 200 per cent of total exports in June. Standard and Poor's said lower Commonwealth external debt was more than offset by rapidly growing private-sector borrowings.
The article continued:
. . . the rating agency said Australia's growing foreign interest payments would slow the process of stabilising the external debt burden.

It placed the responsibility for that very squarely on the shoulders of the private sector in this country. Given the size of the September deficit of over $2 billion, one has to wonder how much worse it will be in, say, the next quarter as tourism earnings fall because of the pilots strike and as we continue to pay foreign companies for the planes that we are hiring from them. Those are not small matters to be taken into account in the short term future of this country's economy.

As any ordinary Australian family knows, when things get a bit tight economically there are really three major options that can be looked at. They can earn more between them, they can spend less between them or they can go into increased debt. There is a short term option available to them-they can sell off everything they own, including those things that are making money for them and hope, like Mr Micawber, that something will show up in due course to get out of the deep hole that they are digging for themselves. What has happened in Australia is that the government of the day has chosen option 2, to cut expenditure. The business sector in Australia has chosen option 3-to go into increasing debt-subsidised, I might add, by the taxpayer because of the tax concessions that are available to them if they move towards debt and away from equity financing.

Worse than all of this, I suppose, is the fact that both the Government and the Opposition are currently leaning more and more towards what I would have thought was the most short-sighted of the options. They are adopting option 4 as a viable part of their strategy, that is, selling off whatever they can to raise short term funds. The recent current account figures are a clear indication that the Government strategies are failing. Yet considering how similar they are to the Opposition strategies, it is really only the matter of pace that is different. One wonders where we are going to be if there is a change of government. Certainly, this Government's policies have led to increased budgetary surpluses. But this has happened only because expenditure on the least well off in the community has been slashed. Australian families are feeling the pinch, which is at least partially the aim of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as he keeps telling us, in order to stop ordinary Australian families from spending money and contributing to our trade deficit by buying imported goods. The Government has made those families feel the pinch by reducing their capacity to spend on locally made products as much as on the imported products. It has been beating them over the head with increasing interest rates to such an extent that many of them cannot even afford the home that they are living in and trying to buy.

Neither of those successes in the eyes of the Government can offset the real problem, namely, that Australian businesses are actually encouraged by the current taxation system to borrow huge amounts of money from overseas. As Standard and Poor's has pointed out, this is a very significant factor in our increasing foreign debt and, hence, in our increasing current account deficit. Until we attend to that problem, we are going to continue to have these sorts of debates on a weekly, if not daily, basis. To make matters worse, the interest paid on those foreign borrowings is tax deductable. First of all, that means the Consolidated Revenue is run down because the money that could go in is not going in there. Secondly, the taxpayer is subsidising those businesses to the point where some of them are paying little or no tax at a time when personal tax payments are increasing because of the fiscal drag.

The Hawke Government's only response to this has been to deregulate the financial system to the point where the only monetary policy weapon left is to bludgeon people around the ears with high interest rates. The Government did that. It deregulated the financial sector with the support of the Opposition. We were promised a better deal from the financial sector. We were told that services would improve, charges would go down and interest rates would go down-that everything would be much better in a deregulated, highly competitive market. Quite the reverse is true. If we do not have an unofficial cartel in the banking industry, I would like to know what we do have, considering the nexus that always seems to obtain between the charges banks impose, the interest rates they each set and the services they offer.

The Opposition has also supported Labor in what I consider to be another short term and short-sighted policy-that is, allowing virtually unfettered foreign investment in Australia. What is even worse is that the major form that this foreign investment has taken is the outright purchasing of property, businesses and so on-not leasing, not minority ownership, but total ownership of urban and rural properties and an increasing ownership of elements of such vital industries in Australia's trade as the beef industry. When one adds to this the fact that both major parties are looking to sell off Australia's most profitable non-private enterprises such as Qantas Airways Ltd and Telecom Australia, we have in place a recipe for a country looking bankruptcy down the throat.

We often look at Japan as a model for where Australia should go. I think it is worthwhile pointing out that the so-called economic miracle in Japan is not something that has come as a result of deregulation. It has come quite specifically as a result over four decades or more of government intervention. That intervention has been put in place to create domestic savings for investment, for a start. A decision was made after the war not to tax the interest on savings in order to provide low interest rate loans to companies that wanted to invest. Japan has also provided government support for businesses until they become viable. It has incorporated a much more cooperative system within industry between management and the factory floor than we have in Australia. Companies have gone as far as providing incentives to work and increase production, profit sharing and other benefits to workers. If we are looking for a model that Australia can pick up and run with, it should not be the deregulatory model that allows businesses to get away with blue murder that we are currently using in Australia. We need a much more government controlled cooperative based system of the sort that applies in Japan and I guess, to a lesser extent, in West Germany. One has to ask why the Australian Government and the Opposition continue to push an economic system and a monetary policy that to date at least it has been proved are not going to work. I do not know for how much longer we have to live under this sort of regime.

I suppose some fairly drastic change is needed to the way in which governments and the Parliament itself operate the fiscal and monetary policies of this country. We could start looking to that issue which Standard and Poor's isolated as the major cause of our problem; that is, foreign borrowings by private companies. It is ludicrous in this country to keep interest rates high in order to encourage foreign investment because we need the foreign investment to offset our foreign borrowings. Those foreign borrowings are not only the catalyst for those two things; they are also causing difficulties with regard to Consolidated Revenue, so that companies such as Bond Corporation and others pay little or no tax. An article appeared in the Age today which indicates that over the past few years four of Australia's most ambitious entrepreneurs and their companies have racked up debts of about $12 billion. If we continue to encourage that when no increased export markets are developed and no additional import replacement items are produced, we are asking for trouble. What we have to do as a primary step is to remove, reduce, or put strictures on the sorts of tax deductions that are offered to private companies in this country when they borrow from overseas. That is the first thing we need to look at.

The second thing we need to do is ask why we do not have a pool of savings in this country that business and industry can use, at much lower interest, for investment purposes. The answer is that we have a prohibitive tax regime applying to the interest that people earn on savings. If Japan can become afloat with money to the point where last year it started to impose a 20 per cent tax on interest, then Australia too can improve its savings pool by offering at least partial relief from the tax burden that individuals face when they put money into banks and building societies, the major lending authorities.

Maybe we need not to look at the policy that Mr Peacock considered and then discarded, inflation indexed taxing, but to take the bottom $1,000 or $2,000 of interest earned and say, `All right, you are not going to be taxed on that, but you will be taxed thereafter'. Certainly, that would encourage savings. There would be an incentive for people who bitterly resent losing 49c in every dollar of interest that they earn and for pensioners who object to the fact that they are paying provisional tax the minute their interest earned reaches $1,000. While we are looking at incentives, let us give some to our rural exporters to help them compete against the subsidies and the dumping policies of our so-called allies-the United States of America and the European Community. If we cannot afford to import, as Treasurers and others complain that we cannot, then we ought to take active steps to reduce imports. If that means using tariff and non-tariff barriers of the sort that many of our trading partners, such as Japan and France, are using, so be it. But until businesses stop borrowing, until we start to make ourselves competitive on international markets, until we protect our export industries and develop new import replacement items, we will not be in a position to see a reduction in our current account deficit and its attendant problem of high interest rates for ordinary Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance submitted to the Senate for discussion by Senator John Stone in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's policy to deal with the fundamental problems of the economy as reflected in the further downgrading of our international credit rating and the continuing crisis in the balance of payments and foreign debt situation.

As Senator Stone said at the outset of his speech, it is a very timely matter of public importance, particularly in light of the circumstances and events which have taken place in the last 24 hours. Even the most objective commentator cannot help observing that this Government is now simply tired and it has lost. It is a failed government, bereft of ideas, initiatives and direction, and, most of all, it has lost hope and a sense of purpose. Perhaps this is best epitomised by the meandering, discursive and stumbling performance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the last week. He has finally dropped his bag. We saw him on the Face to Face program, on the Sunday program and then at the Metal Trades Industry Association dinner. He now knows that he is at a dead end. He is out of ideas and, tragically, Australia for the time being is out of luck. In my eight years in both government and opposition, I have not seen a more dispirited and dejected bunch than I see sitting opposite me for the better part of most days. They have the smell of death about them-it reeks in their nostrils-and they are showing all the hallmarks of the Unsworth Government. Their attitude is simply, `Let us hang on and hope that something will turn up'. No doubt in retrospect they are now all aching for the prospect of a half Senate election. They know that that is off the agenda because it would be the Bass by-election all over again, but they would dearly love to have another six months of a wish list of hope that something might turn up by accident. They all know that as that is now off the agenda they are in very real trouble.

This Government has failed on almost every single count. Worst of all, it has failed most dismally in the area of integrity. I raise that matter particularly because it goes to the heart of the conduct of the economic management of this Government. I am reminded of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the early years of this Government depicted in cartoons-I think they were in the Australian-carrying around his little box labelled `Integrity'. We know what is said about men who have to talk about their integrity. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer, Mr Keating, have said, `Trust us'. For six years the people have been trusting the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. I ask: How many families in Australia can put their hands up now and say, `I am better off, my family is better off, my kids are better off and my mortgage is easier to cope with since the day the Australian Labor Party was elected.'?

TALK.START.PARA: —With no children living in poverty.
—We were told that no children would be living in poverty by 1990. As for integrity, the Prime Minister gets zero out of 10.
—Mr Hawke couldn't even spell it.

—That is right. I notice in the cartoons that the integrity box has gone too: that has disappeared off the newspapers. This is a Government which in rhetoric takes the high moral ground but in practice adopts the policy of the lowest common denominator. It has consistently claimed that it is a responsible government committed to making tough economic decisions which are for the long term national good.
—Like Coronation Hill.

—That is right. It is not driven by political expediency, it does not have its eye on the next election, it does not have its eye on short term political advantage, and it is not worrying itself about votes; it is worrying about the high moral ground, the well-being of Australian citizens in the future! We are told that the Government can take these tough decisions because the Prime Minister, rising to the height of 5 foot 4 1/2 inches, tells us all that the Australian community, the Australian voters, are sufficiently mature to accept the medicine that is necessary to readjust economically so that we have a sustained economy for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the reality of this Government? It is one of expediency, equivocation, vacillation, dithering and, worst of all, flight with fear when confronting what has to be done to put this country in a position where ordinary Australians have some economic hope for the future. I will take up Senator Stone's point. Let us look at the most recent graphic example of duplicity, economic delinquency and crude political expediency. The decision was not taken in the national good or in the national interest. Rather, it was taken for the political good of the Australian Labor Party-a grubby decision made at enormous cost to all Australian taxpayers in a desperate bid by this Government to grab a hatful of votes, to allow it to cling to the last vestige of power. It was a decision based on broken promises, cowardly determinations and financial irresponsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't wait. What is it?

—I am talking about the Coronation Hill case. Johnny Smith's four-year-old kid could have picked what I was on about with that number of clues. If we had been on the Tony Barber show the first buzzer would have gone off in one second. It is a question of total economic irresponsibility and a lack of integrity. The two simple things that the Prime Minister claims to be his strong suit are integrity and long term considerations. The Prime Minister had promised the Chairman of Directors of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), Sir Arvi Parbo--
—In writing.

—He promised him in writing that Coronation Hill would proceed. So BHP, foolishly in retrospect, spent $14m at the end of the day proving up an ore reserve, only to find that the deal was off. Yet it was told that the project could proceed. What did the Government do? The Prime Minister spoke first from the chair of Cabinet and put his imprimatur on the decision. In addition, the decision was made to close down the conservation zone-another broken promise for future exploration. What is the net result? The average Australian taxpayer is $500m worse off straight up. Add to that this bizarre three-mine uranium policy, arrived at for the same reason, politically expediently driven, which stops Jabiluka, Koongarra and a whole range of other mines getting off the ground. The best estimates by the Government's own Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics indicate that the resources of those mines are worth about $70 billion. That used to be about three-quarters of our national debt; it has now shrunk to almost half. That decision was arrived at as a result of the Prime Minister spending 90 minutes talking to the leader of a conservation group and getting his starting orders. When the Chairman of Directors of BHP rang up to put his oar in the water, to remind the Prime Minister of his promise, he had to leave his message scribbled on a pad with a secretary. That is the Prime Minister's judgment as to how we ought to be making these decisions.
—He didn't want to talk to him.

—He did not want to talk to him. What could he say to him? Senator Robert Ray asked about Qantas Airways Ltd and talked generally about privatisation. Let us talk about privatisation. What is the Government's attitude to micro-economic reform, privatisation and selling off all government corporations? We were told at the beginning of this parliamentary term and after the 1987 election that this would be a period of micro-economic reform. What have we seen? Mr Keating has endorsed the push by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to have Labor's anti-privatisation policy changed before the next election; yesterday Mr Hawke endorsed a ministerial call for the full sale of Qantas and Australian Airlines; and Mr Willis has strongly urged that sale. What has the Government done about it? It has done absolutely nothing. It knows what it is costing. This year alone Qantas is expected to have to raise $600m in borrowings because it cannot get the capital equity it requires.
—They finished up not with a bang but with a whimper.

—That is right; it finished up with a whimper. Because of Qantas's present situation the average Australian passenger is paying 20 per cent extra. The fact that Qantas is not able to be sold off is costing about $350m in inbound tourism. Why can it not be sold off? It is because Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and Mr Willis get to the barrier, get frightened and tear away because they have the Right of Victoria, the Right of New South Wales, the Left right across the nation and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) telling them, `You will not sell'.
—The Public Service unions.

—And the Public Service unions. Who is running this country? That tough leader who is prepared to make the tough decisions? I'll bet! Let us look at the waterfront. Senator Robert Ray asked us a moment ago about the waterfront and coastal shipping. What has the Government done about that? In 1987 there were 250 different disputes on the waterfront, affecting about 360 ships. It is estimated that capital equipment on the waterfront is running at about 40 per cent capacity. If the proposals of the Inter-State Commission had been adopted it could have saved Australia approximately $620m.
—Every year.
—Every year. What did the Government do about it? It did absolutely nothing other than to pledge $154m of Australian taxpayers' money to pay off 3,000 members.
—The Waterside Workers Federation.
—To pay off waterside workers for early retirement above and beyond their normal entitlements for things such as superannuation, long service leave and their other perks.
—To spend their lives doing nothing.

—Yes. Compare them with the pilots. The Government is providing Ansett Airlines of Australia with hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds to screw a white collar union notorious for being outside the ACTU accord and for having scant regard for the politics of the Labor Party. What do we see when it comes to micro-economic reform? We see absolutely nothing. That is the hallmark, the history and the track record of this Government. It is anticipated that we would save $550m annually if we could reform coastal shipping. So we have the spectre of this Government claiming that economic policy is being run for the long term economy and not for the election.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, I have almost run out of time but I wish to remind the Senate of one thing. Mr Keating told us that he would not make any projections about interest rates, that he was not in the business of making such projections because of elections. He said:
Well, I mean, economic policy is going to be run for the economy and not for an election,
Referring to the Prime Minister, he said:
He is not out there making pronouncements about interest rates and neither am I.
Let us turn to what happened in late January or early February this year. The Prime Minister was reported as follows:
Home loan interest rates will not rise any further before they fall later this year, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said today.
He said that on 29 January when interest rates were at 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Perth during the Western Australian election.

—In Perth during the Western Australian election. The tragedy is that the promise of lower interest rates wrecks the very purpose of high interest rates. First of all, it gives the wrong market signals to the international money market and, secondly, in terms of domestic consumption and demand, it gives people a false belief in their capacity to purchase. So demand goes up and the economy remains heated. That is why the economy is in the mess it is. That is the level of irresponsibility of this Prime Minister.
—Mr Keating speaking with both forks.

—That is right. Now we have the great deregulators. What is the very last thing they have done? At a cost of $200m of taxpayers' money, they have regulated the banks by subsidising them to put a cap on certain levels of interest rates. So much for the deregulators, so much for micro-economic performance, and so much for economic responsibility. Of course, we are told that this is a Government for the long haul.
—It has lost its way.
—Of course it has lost its way.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here today a matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Stone which is basically critical of what he describes as the failure of the Government to deal with the fundamental problems of the economy. Senator Stone is correct in the sense that he strongly supports governments facing up to fundamental changes to an economy, which our economy needs and has needed for a very long time. So I am in agreement with him there. But that is as far as our agreement goes because it is Senator Stone's solutions, particularly as they come from a man who has had experience as the head of Treasury, his understanding of the problems and the advice he has given in that role as an influential economic guru, that have in many cases been wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of those fundamental problems facing Australia before I return to Senator Stone's prescription. First, for more than 30 years we have had an economy insulated from the rest of the world and basically uncompetitive and a group of businessmen and governments that were unwilling to see that a domestic market is not sufficient to sustain both primary and manufacturing industries. Secondly, the productivity of our work force, both at a management and at a worker level, has needed to be dramatically improved by world standards, especially by the standards of our competitors overseas. But I stress there that it was both a management and a worker problem. Thirdly, our taxation system needed to be constantly reviewed to ensure that it was fair, that it was seen to be fair and that it rewarded the true entrepreneur and not the paper shufflers and those who expend their time and energy in rorting the system rather than competing out in the real world.

When this Government came to office it was determined to address all three of those problems. If I have time I will expand on the Government's program later on in my speech. I mention this at the outset because it is important to put this debate in its historical context so that the debate about the solutions is a little more sophisticated and productive than is usually the case in this chamber. Historically, we have been the lucky country. In many ways successive governments, mainly of a conservative persuasion, have failed either to see the problems or to address them with intelligence, courage and tenacity. It is not easy. We all understand that in any democracy-Australia is like most democracies-the government has to deal with the power of lobby groups and vested interest groups attempting to preserve their special positions. In many ways those positions have been counterproductive in toto to the national interest. Of course, government has a major role to play in not only balancing the interest groups and maintaining itself in office but also making the hard decisions which in the long term will make us competitive by world standards without necessarily losing our cultural and social advantages.

Senator Stone is leaving the chamber. It is interesting to note that he was the Opposition spokesman in this debate because he has been and still is very much part of that syndrome which has thwarted Australia's moves to be competitive and its capacity as a nation to address the fundamental problems inherent in our economy. In some cases Senator Stone's recommendations about economic policy have been plainly wrong. In others his attacks on Government reforms have been politically biased. Either way he has been very much part of that old guard which has been responsible for many of the problems or difficulties that Australia faces today. He has been an integral part of the decision making process over the last 30 years which has brought us to the situation which needs to be remedied here and now.

During those many years Australia relied on a policy of running down its manufacturing sector at the expense of promoting its mining and farming sectors. That has been a fact of political life in this country for more than 30 years. It is a fundamental flaw in economic thinking, which this Government is desperately trying to overcome in its major policy programs. I will give one example of why over the last 30 years Australia has pursued this failed line. A lot of it comes back to the thinking of people such as Senator Stone.

I refer honourable senators to a paper entitled `Australia in a Competitive World-Some Options' which he, as Secretary to the Treasury, presented to the twenty-first general management conference of the Australian Institute of Management in Sydney on 19 November 1979. I will quote from page 4 of that paper because it gives us an indication of not only the way Senator Stone thought and still thinks but also the way in which he could be so totally wrong in his predictions about what would happen to the economy and what needed to be done. If he, when he was Secretary to the Treasury, could present this viewpoint in a paper to such an august body and be so blatantly wrong, how are we to believe him today when he comes into this chamber and starts to criticise this Government for the way it is trying to renew this economy after 30 years of total and absolute negligence and wrong direction taking on the part of previous governments? At that conference Senator Stone said:

Rather, I want to note the expectation of a strong growth of mineral exports on which they were based-an expectation I agree with. I want also to note that even in the brief time since those fears were current the outlook for energy exports has immeasurably strengthened. In short, in the decade ahead-
we should remember that this was in 1979-
there seems every reason to believe that we are going to be very successful at exporting.
That brings me to my first major point which is this: the more successful, in the decade ahead, we prove to be at exporting, the more successful we are also going to have to be at importing.

He went on further about the impact of a future export based boom in Australia. How quaint and out of date those ideas of the young J. O. Stone, Secretary to the Treasury, now appear to be in a country in which imports are far outstripping exports, in which the mining and energy products boom has crawled to a standstill, leaving us with enormous infrastructure debts to service, and in which our competitiveness as a manufacturing country has only slightly improved. That is apart from the situation in which we find ourselves now in which the prices for our commodities have been reduced by a value close to $6 billion. Yet in that 1979 speech the young J. O. Stone, before his reincarnation in the Senate, was happily predicting a brave new world in which Australia in the future would be cashed up and would require more expenditure on imports to soak up the liquidity caused by an export boom especially in commodities-a boom which never occurred.

By coming into this chamber today to tell this Government how it should be organising the economy and to talk about the fundamental flaws in our economic thinking and economic policy, Senator Stone is exposed not only for the charlatan he was in those days but for the viewpoints that he had which were so totally wrong. Heaven help us if the treasury bench was to be occupied by the same man who was so wrong less than a decade ago. But, of course, Senator Stone was a victim of the circumstances of the day. He was reflecting a commonly held view amongst both the conservatives and Treasury-in many cases they were one and the same-and by their conservative political masters who governed this country for so long during that crucial period of the 1950s and 1960s. That was a time when Australia had sufficient prosperity to enable it to make vital structural changes that would make it competitive in the 1980s and 1990s.

In short, I am saying that the conservatives threw away the opportunity to change this country for the better and to do it with less pain than is now necessary under a genuine reformist Labor Government. To summarise that conservative attitude, I need to repeat the fallacy that has set us so far behind-the fallacy held and pushed by those people. First, they believed that the manufacturing industry in this country was less important to our national standard of living than it really is. They were prepared to protect the manufacturing industry behind a wall of high tariffs, import quotas and an overvalued dollar. But that protection had nothing to do with making it competitive in terms of export potential.

Secondly, the government of those days was able to hide the structural problems by using a policy of heavy unemployment to dampen down consumer demand, sedating the economy in effect while simply waiting for something to turn up with our traditional exports. Thirdly, the conservatives believed that the international resources boom would solve Australia's problems, that we would be flooded with wealth from shale oil, coal, exported energy and other projects as described in their 1980 election campaign, which was an attempt to create a false picture of an expected boom. Fourthly, they borrowed as a Federal government and encouraged State governments, semi-government instrumentalities and Australian industry to borrow in massive amounts the loans necessary to fund infrastructure development for this anticipated boom. Fifthly, they were never able to address the issue of increasing productivity and creating a labour market that was not responsible for wage caused inflation. Their approach was fundamentally one that could be described as an ivory tower based upon the view that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the industrial relations structures needed to be abolished so that the law of the jungle would reduce union power and dampen down wage demands. This was a very simplistic view about what needed to be done.

The conservatives were never able to do as this Government has done, which was to create changes within the existing structures that would increase productivity, reduce real wages, reduce industrial disputes and create an atmosphere of cooperation between unions, management and the economy. Because they would not take on the structures of the day and try to stretch them to accommodate the changes that we have been able to make, they were doomed to failure. They were simply trying to knock down Australia's industrial relations structures rather than trying to work productively within those structures.

What have they learned from those past mistakes in which Senator Stone was intimately involved? The answer is almost nothing. For example, let us look at the labour market question that Senator Stone talks about so often and that Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned today. Senator Stone and his supporters continue to push the line that the accord between the Government and the unions is a disaster for Australia. Yet that flies in the face of the fact that for the first time since 1949 real wages have dropped in a time of high economic growth. That is a vital factor in making Australia competitive and taking the problem of wage demand caused by inflation out of the system. For example, since 1949 there have been five occasions when a year of weak economic growth has been followed by at least three years of strong economic growth. Much of the benefits of that strong economic growth has been diminished by the fact that real wages did not decline or stay static and increased in most cases during those periods of boom by at least 6.7 per cent.

Where was the Australian government in those days? Who was in charge of the Treasury? It was none other than J. O. Stone, the man who is bringing before this Senate today a criticism of the way in which this Government is operating in terms of its economic reform and its attention to the fundamental issues that confront this economy. The accord has been today's Government's method of achieving growth without an increase in real wages, in other words, maintaining some competitiveness on a wage level with our counterparts overseas. That could only have been done through the accord, and in no other way. It involved cooperation, understanding and a broadening of the issues in relation to our discussions with the unions.

We have set out in terms of industry plans to try to make Australian manufacturers more competitive. It will not be achieved overnight. We have had 30 years of conservative government, 30 years of conservative policy to overcome. The trouble with the economic debates that occur in this chamber is that people are looking at what is happening now, today and maybe tomorrow. They are not looking at the long term development of policy, the long term implementation of policy, and the cooperation that is necessary within the Australian community to achieve those goals and make sure that we are part of a world marketplace. That is to do with attitudes and will not be changed overnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance we are considering relates to the failure of the Government's policy to deal with the fundamental problems of the economy. Senator Aulich's contribution makes it very clear what the problem is. The Government does not seem to understand in the slightest what the real fundamental problems of our economy are. We are living beyond our means to the tune of $22 billion a year. Since this Labor Government came to power we have borrowed $85 billion to maintain our current standard of living. We are now the third most indebted country in the world to overseas banks. We have just overtaken Mexico. It is often said that this debt is largely private and therefore it does not matter. The Government's own Reserve Bank made it quite clear that that was economic nonsense. Debts, whether private or public, have to be serviced out of the Australian economy. In any case the reason there is so much private borrowing overseas is the economic policies of the Government, the drying up of savings, the fact that it is now easier and cheaper to borrow overseas than to try to borrow in Australia. This is the inevitable result of the economic policies of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We are like a family living recklessly beyond our means on hire purchase and credit cards, saying, `Look how well we are doing'. Eventually the credit card debts and the hire purchase debts come in. They are coming in now for this Government. How did this Government get us in this appalling mess? When it took office in 1983 there was a world recession. In this country there was the most severe drought of modern times. It had the benefit of a wage freeze introduced by the Fraser Government. Straight after it took office the world recession ended and our terms of trade improved. The drought broke. I am sure that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thinks that it was his intervention that broke the drought. Economically it was very dramatic. In the first year or so of this Government things were improving economically. It was nothing to do with the Government; it was entirely to do with external factors.

In the early years of the Labor Government the Treasurer, Mr Keating, introduced some beneficial economic management plans. They were, in fact, coalition policies that were in the pipeline when the government changed. But at least he introduced them. Unfortunately, there was one crucial failure. He deregulated the financial markets but did not deregulate the labour market. In that respect he has the worst of all worlds. That system cannot work. He has deregulated the financial markets but kept the labour market very rigid. As we have seen in the last six years that is a recipe for disaster. Nevertheless, the deregulation efforts of Mr Keating did get him the award for the world's best finance Minister. What his supporters do not often mention is that two years later he was the runner-up for the title of the world's worst finance Minister. They do not mention that very much. That is a more realistic appraisal of the consequences of having this Treasurer.

Since the Treasurer used up the ideas he inherited he has frankly just run out of ideas. He now uses vulgar and childish abuse when anyone questions what he is doing, abuse at a level most year 11 students would regard as excessively juvenile. His problem also is that he picks up on ideas that he only half understands. He thinks they are the cure-all for our problems. Do honourable senators remember the J-curve and how that was going to cure our balance of payments problems? We do not hear of the J-curve these days. We were told that interest rates would solve the problem of excessive demand created, incidentally, by the Government's economic policies. Interest rates were going to be held tight and we were going to cure our economic problems, ignoring the negative effects of these high interest rates and the very great pain they inflict on people, particularly home owners. To some extent he is trying to alleviate that by a rather sordid deal of $200m with the banks to hold down interest rates on home loans. He ignored the fact that others have to pay for those and, nevertheless, he did that. He ignored the pain of that. He ignored the effect of high interest rates on investment which he desperately needed in the manufacturing industry. He ignored the effect on inflation, which, at 7 to 8 per cent, is much higher than that of our competitors. Above all, he ignored the very great damage that these high interest rates do to the value of the Australian dollar, holding it higher than it should be on economic terms and making our exports and import replacements much more difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, and making the cost of local production much higher.

—Yes, it makes our import replacement industries much less competitive because our dollar is overvalued. What we have is a government in a state of terminal disintegration. Mr Kerin very accurately and openly criticises the absurd economic decisions made by the Government. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) at least is economically rational. I know that he is away sick, but I think that he is also away fed up with the way that economic management is going on in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has nowhere to go. What it is hoping for rather forlornly is some export upsurge. The problem is that, in the two key areas of wool and wheat, there will be no upsurge this year. Wool prices are down and wheat quantities are down, so we cannot look for any help there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wool is down about a billion dollars.

—A billion dollars down, as Senator Crichton-Browne says, for wool this year. That has to be made up some other way. Any halfway economically literate government would be looking at ways of solving this problem. What must the Government do? Firstly, one would think that it would be looking at improving internal savings so that it does not have to borrow so much overseas. Personally I am in favour of a consumption tax which would improve savings, provided-I emphasise `provided'-it was matched by a corresponding fall in the take from income tax. Nevertheless, the extraordinarily inept handling of the whole consumption tax issue by the Treasurer has put it off the political agenda for some years, to the great detriment of the economy of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Then one would think that the Government would look at other ways of raising income, and one is tourism. What has this Government done to tourism? It has engineered the most stupid and damaging strike in recent memory. The airline pilots strike has done enormous damage to our tourism industry, and not just temporarily; it will be years before our tourism industry recovers from the damage done by the Government very largely but not entirely, because the airline pilots have a good deal to answer for. Basically, the handling of the dispute by the Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, has been extraordinarily clumsy and stupid, with great damage to this country and its tourism industry in particular.

Then one would think the Government would realise that we must have more exports. One would think that it would look at mining. What does it do for the mining industry? It makes bizarre judgments, changes the rules, breaks its word and damages its whole reputation in relation to the mining industry, to the great detriment of our export income and the interests of all the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you go into a joint venture with BHP at Coronation Hill again?

—Senator Crichton-Browne mentions Coronation Hill, and that is the most recent one; but it is not the only one. There have been many others in which the Government has no set rules which people trying to invest in extractive industries can go by. If they cannot be certain that the ground will be held to, they will not invest. The losers will be the Australian economy and the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: One would think also that any halfway rational government would look at improving our ports and shipping, because they are central to any exports. The Government has not tackled the problems with our ports. It has done a deal with the unions so that they get about $250m, or $100,000 per person. The productivity rise promised I doubt will ever be delivered. The unions say quite frankly that they can give no guarantees that it will be delivered. We do not have time to discuss all of the manifold defects of our coastal shipping and overseas shipping industries, but they are very severe and have not been seriously tackled by this Government.

Above all, one would think that the Government would be tackling manufacturing productivity. In the six years of this Government, the rise in manufacturing productivity is almost zero. In six years it has not done anything. Productivity in other countries is rising steadily; ours is not. Not only are we not catching up, but we are falling further and further behind. Australians can be very productive. In the agricultural sector we are probably the most productive country per head in the world. If we could get rid of the shackles that the Government and our industrial relations system impose on the Australian worker, we could be one of the most productive countries in the world. We have to tackle these problems, and the Government just does not.

I listened with some interest to the solution to these problems that was put forward by Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats. On my understanding of what she was saying, she seemed to be espousing the doctrine of General Peron, the President of the Argentine, who led the Argentine down the track to a total economic collapse. The only bit of Peronism that Senator Haines forgot to mention was a reference to the shirtless ones. I do not think that we can pay much attention to their solutions, but what we must look at is what the Opposition can do that the Government does not do. We will inherit a real mess next year. There are many things that we must tackle. The first is that we must control government expenditure so that we are living within our means: not what we would like to do but what we can afford to do.

Secondly, we must privatise as many government instrumentalities as possible. By the way, the aim is not to transfer a public monopoly to a private monopoly. Although it would be a bit better, a private monopoly is not that much better than a public one. What we must do is to privatise so as to increase competition because competition is the key to economic efficiency. That must be the aim of our privatisation-to improve competition, to remove monopolies. And the Government will not tackle privatisation. It talks about it but it does nothing.

The third area which we must tackle but which the Government will not tackle is industrial relations. Our industrial relations are a very unhappy blend of English trade union systems and multiple unions with a `them and us' philosophy. We have a highly centralised and legalistic wage fixing and dispute settling mechanism, a system that was fashionable in the 1890s and has proved over a 100 years not to work. Finally, we have a very unfortunate division of responsibility between Federal and State governments imposed by our Constitutions. The results are awful.

What we desperately need and must work towards if we wish to get out of our economic mess is an industrial relations system that has one union in each workplace so that the people in each workplace are insulated from disputes in other workplaces that do not concern them. Finally, the workers in each workplace, in each enterprise, must have an involvement in the success and profitability of their enterprise, both in the wage fixing area and in the profit sharing area. These are the things we must do. We must work towards those as quickly as we can. Without that, we are heading steadily down the South American road.

The Government is moving in the opposite direction from this. What it wants is bigger, more powerful and more influential unions, with multiple unions in each workplace in most cases-very powerful ones, totally divorced from the local concerns. In my view, this would be an economic disaster. As I said, the Government is opposed to privatisation. It will not move down that road at all.

The Government will not restrain expenditure. It believes in buying off its friends. Remember the $150m given to the waterfront, to buy off workers who have not been doing a proper day's work for years, and buying off Kodak with $60m to stay in Australia. Look at what it is doing for its friend Sir Peter Abeles in the airline industry. Look at what it did for Alan Bond. What it is doing is using public money to buy off its friends. It tries to buy off-or buy, I suppose, rather than buy off-its other friends in the environmental movement by taking economically disastrous decisions because they will be popular with the environmental movement. I do not say for a moment that environmental factors should not be properly taken into account in making economic decisions, but this Government is handling them by making irrational and economically very damaging decisions without proper consideration of anything other than what it thinks will affect the results in the ballot boxes in marginal seats. That is not the way to run a successful economy. This Government is a total economic failure. The sooner this country is rid of it, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One disappointing aspect of the debate this afternoon, until we came to the last speaker-and I shall mention something about him in a moment-has been that the Opposition has not articulated to the Australian public what its alternative strategy is, if it has one. It is not necessarily disappointing to have criticism of the Government, as we had this afternoon, but it is disappointing that the criticism has not been tempered with some indication to the Government and to the public of what the alternative strategy of the Opposition is. I can remember well that, when we were in opposition and had debates like this, we were critical of the Government-and rightly so-but we also outlined our alternative strategy. Over months, and perhaps even years, it was possible for the Australian public to see the Australian Labor Party's strategy. It was possible for that to be debated in here and in the community. That is probably the reason why we are now on this side.

SPEECH.PARA: All we heard today from the Opposition, until we heard the last speaker, Senator Hamer, was criticism. At least he put down some alternative roads that perhaps the Government and the country could look at going down. Unfortunately, at present the Opposition is not willing to take some of those roads. For instance, we have been told that, in the event of a change of government, there would not be a consumption tax in the first term but that it would perhaps be looked at after that. Some of the aspects that Senator Hamer mentioned, such as privatisation, probably are part of the Opposition's strategy. Privatisation does not fit readily with the stance of many on this side of the House, but I would have preferred speakers opposite to at least put forward some strategy, and perhaps to outline an Opposition strategy, rather than the type of personal strategy that Senator Hamer put forward.

The alternative strategy that the Government does have is the Opposition's economic plan, which was much vaunted. It was a frequently debated plan but it is now a really discredited plan. After years of thought, planning and analysing the Opposition has come up with a dud. I suppose that the Opposition believes that its economic plan is an irresistible vote catcher. I was rather amazed to see something recently which reminded me of these irresistible vote catchers. It happened in Queensland. On the very hour that the election date was announced, the Minister in charge of transport in Queensland, whoever that was-it is pretty hard to keep up with Queensland because it has had 36 Ministers in the last three years-said, `We've got something that we'll give the Queensland public as soon as we're re-elected, although it won't be until July next year: every child will be able to travel for one dollar a week on the trains in Queensland'. I presume he meant the suburban trains. One dollar a week for all children sounded very good, until it was realised that some children already travel free as they have free passes to go to school.

I will go back to the policy on which the credibility of this Opposition rests. Senator Robert Ray and, I think, Senator Aulich mentioned that the Opposition's economic plan was flawed according to Department of Finance assessments. Apparently even Mr Connolly seemed confused by the figures in his own policy on child-care. My old friend Ron McAuliffe used to refer to David Miles Connolly as `David Smiles Cunningly'. But I do not think that Mr Connolly was smiling this week when he became confused about his policy on child-care. It is no wonder that this afternoon's attack did not try to rely on this as an alternative. It just cannot be done. The credibility of the Opposition as a potential government is now in tatters.

Senator Stone waxed at length about the balance of payments and overseas debt, but he and the Opposition have comprehensively failed to address any practical solutions to Australia's balance of payments and external debt. Instead, Mr Peacock-and therefore Senator Stone by implication-has chosen to base his entire economic strategy upon the most vulnerable area of his policy, which of course is wages. It must be remembered that the Opposition has never presided over an economy governed by the vagaries of a floating exchange rate. Having not done that, it fails to comprehend the effects of fluctuating global economic conditions on Australia's external debt. It fails to appreciate the subsequent domino effect of the type of wages breakout which would have resulted from the Opposition's capitulation to the demands of the airline pilots. The previous speaker, Senator Hamer, mentioned something about that dispute, but he did not analyse its underlying dangers to the Australian economy. He glossed over them, as so many in the Opposition have done. The Opposition fails to understand the enormous brutality of overseas markets, particularly if they are offended in policy terms. It seems not to be concerned about how dependent we are on often fragile markets.

Let us look at the domestic front. The Opposition would choose to shatter the successful consensus model, which has ushered in an unprecedented era of wage restraint and industrial harmony. As my colleague Senator Aulich said just a few minutes ago, the Opposition seems to be obsessed with destroying the accord and would, in the process, court international concern as the stability of Australia's wages policy was opened up. The failure of the Opposition to appreciate the watershed and disastrous effect of a fractured wages policy on the external financial markets would result in it consigning this nation to the economic dustbin.

The destruction of the accord mechanism in favour of direct bargaining is the Opposition's plan. Yet enterprise bargaining outside any system of industrial jurisdiction would result in wage increases far greater than under an accord. Wage increases would be far greater for some time, but I wonder whether in the long term this would be in the best interests of the economy. I believe that it would not. We would probably end up with what has often been predicted by Senator Stone, namely, a recession. I sometimes wonder whether that is what the Opposition wants. In a recession interest rates would be far higher than they are now. In a recession the Opposition would see us walking away from an agreed income determination structure to one in which craft unions had to negotiate with individual enterprises. Under this type of policy, whereby we might be moving towards a recession, we would be staring down the barrel of interest rates much higher than they are now.

This is the sort of grim scenario that Australians would be faced with under a Peacock, Hewson and Stone-if he is re-elected to the seat of Fairfax-economic plan. Compare this recipe for a recession and resultant collapse in investment with the Government's firm resolve to continue with the wages accord; compare it with the Government's determination to press on with the restructuring of our manufacturing base and its plans to create a position for bringing into balance the overseas trade deficit. The Opposition has failed to take the hard decisions and present the Australian public with a strong alternative economic policy. The Government is proud to stand by its record in the field of economic management and innovative policies.

Unlike almost any other government in the developed world, the Hawke Labor Government has successfully implemented a strategy which has attacked inflation and unemployment at the same time. The Government has recognised that only through a growing economy can effective assistance be provided to the needy in the community. Our economic strategy, forged with the Australian people and the trade union movement through the accord, has been an outstanding success. It is worth mentioning that Australia has emerged from the inherited Fraser doldrums economy of 1983 to be one of the fastest growing economies in the world. I can well remember being in this place in 1982 and the early part of 1983 when, month after month, more and more people became unemployed. That contrasts with what has happened since we have been in government. More than 1 1/2 million jobs have been created. More than 1 1/2 million more people are now in the work force, being productive and not a drain on the economy, than would have been the case if we had carried on with the strategies of the Fraser Government.

Inflation is not as low as we would like, but it must be remembered that it is far lower than it was when we came to government in 1983. The massive Budget deficit of the Fraser years has been transformed into a record surplus. We have reformed the Australian economy and we are restructuring and modernising our manufacturing base to ensure that we can compete effectively in the international marketplace. The Government has been the party of change, of reform on an unparalleled scale and of innovation and ideas. Under this Government the financial system has been deregulated, the tax system has been made fairer, the labour market is being restructured and we are eliminating abuse in the welfare system. Australia has become more flexible, more dynamic and more competitive.

Part of the revitalisation of our manufacturing base has relied on modernisation through the purchase of new equipment. Obviously, much of this equipment must be purchased overseas, and this investment has placed pressure on the balance of payments. The major component of imports driven by demand for capital goods accounted for approximately 40 per cent of the increase in the total of imports. This naturally reflects to our detriment in terms of the balance of payments in the short term but, in the long run, this investment will give Australian industry a far greater capacity to produce export and import-replacing output. This will be vital to any substantial improvement in the balance of payments.

Obviously, the high demand for imported goods and machinery may continue to be reflected in a relatively high imbalance of payments. However, this Government has made a long term commitment to stimulate a sustained recovery of those many manufacturing industries which ground into obsolescence under the inertia of the economy during the Fraser Government. The strategy of the Hawke Labor Government is to cut the current account deficit, and is also directed towards stabilising and reducing the level of foreign debt which is currently growing at a rate that we do not think is satisfactory, and one which we are addressing. In relation to the matter before us, all I would say is that we look forward to criticism, but we also look for some strategy from the Opposition as to what it would do if it happened to be in government which would give us something to debate.

This report from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) is most disappointing. It is a report which was called for by legislation passed in December last year, at the insistence of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, for this Parliament to be informed about two particular innovations on the part of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). They are, firstly, the profile system in a unified national system of higher education in this country, which has been a great step backwards because of its centralised control of higher education and, secondly, the higher education contribution scheme-the graduate tax-and the impositions it has brought to Australia's 400,000 higher education students. Because of these quite important innovations we in this Parliament wanted to know, periodically, what the evaluation by the Higher Education Council of these two schemes is and the Council, through NBEET, has reported to the Minister.

First of all, the report is disappointing because it is late. Parliament insisted, in the Bill that was before it then, that there be reports in February and August. Here it is, towards the end of October, and the Minister has brought this report to our attention only now. Already there is planning in train, not only by the Minister and his Department, NBEET and higher education institutions, but even by us in this Parliament, with regard to schemes for next year, and we have been delayed in gaining this report until the end of October.

Secondly, there is nothing in the report of any real substance. There is a brief mention of the higher education contribution scheme that detailed that conclusions on the impact of the scheme would not be able to be made-I quote from page 9-`until February 1990 at the earliest'. So, a full year and a half of planning and operation of this new scheme and its impact on all of the higher education students in Australia will not be able to be evaluated in the way that this Parliament has called for until February next year.

If the Minister sits on the report from the Higher Education Council in the way in which he has on the August and February reports this year, the Parliament will not see it perhaps until after Easter. By that time we might be in the last weeks of the Hawke Labor Government because the election would be upon us and there would be a change of government but without this Parliament having the up-to-date evaluation of the higher education contribution scheme. It is not good enough to give vague statements in this manner when the Parliament has expressly called for a more detailed response. With regard to profiles, I find it perplexing that the Higher Education Council, including its chairman, Dr Gregor Ramsey, has chosen language in this report that is totally accommodating to the Minister's White Paper, totally accommodating to the Minister's views of being integrated with the Department. I rise to speak to the medical research report 1988 put out by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). This report tells us that Australia has a very high reputation in the field of medical research and deservedly so. The report documents a large number and a very considerable range of research projects which have been funded by the NHMRC under the Medical Research Endowment Act. While appreciative of the amount and high quality of the research which is described in this report I wish to make some comments about the broad direction of medical research in this country as revealed in the report.

The first point I would like to make is that I gain the impression from the report that the primary focus of medical research in Australia is on the cure of disease and the correction of problems rather than on prevention. I believe that it is time for the NHMRC to review the focus of its research activities and to begin to place the emphasis on research which will improve our ability to prevent sickness and accidents. Over the past 80 years or so medical research aimed at the curing of disease has had some spectacular successes. Mortality rates have been reduced and life expectancy has been increased. But as things now stand, it would appear likely that greater and greater expenditure on research aimed at finding cures will yield relatively smaller rates of success than in the past. Research in these areas which yields successful techniques tends to result in high technology medical developments which are increasingly expensive. As our national health bill grows from year to year and consumes more and more of the funds available to the Government to provide services to the community, the time must inevitably come when we simply will not be able to afford to use all of the high technology medical options which may be available to us. It is also true that the high technology curative options which are often invasive, while these may prolong life, do not necessarily yield improved quality of life. On the other hand, research which promotes prevention will yield enormous benefits at relatively small cost. This would also tend to preserve an enhanced quality of life at the same time.

I have scanned the report to ascertain whether the NHMRC is involved in any research into the prevalence and prevention of iatrogenic disease in Australia. As far as I can see this topic is not covered in any of the research projects documented in the report. Iatrogenic disease is disease or disability brought about unintentionally by doctors and other health workers in their attempts to cure problems reported to them by patients. Iatrogenic disease may result from incorrect diagnosis, leading to incorrect treatment and the exacerbation of the condition or the development of new problems. It may result from gross errors. It may result from errors in prescription-overprescription and overservicing-or it may result from sociological factors.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that on 8 June I spoke of the use of epidural injections of a drug known as Dep-romedrol which is used for the treatment of back pain. I tabled a number of statutory declarations from persons who claim that their health had been adversely affected by this form of treatment. I am certain that there are other forms of iatrogenic disease which are as damaging, as expensive and as unrecognised as were these epidural injections which I raised just some weeks ago. I am glad to be able to report that the Western Australian Department of Health has now approached the NHMRC and asked it to investigate the epidurals. I hope that a research project will soon be launched on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report of the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure actually deals with an issue that goes back quite some time. SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned here essentially with the way in which we proceed. There is an enormous amount of debate in this place about how everybody else in the community ought to improve procedures and increase productivity. It goes on and on endlessly. When it comes to this place, we suddenly find that a reverse argument applies. There must be no changes, there must be no updating and there must be no streamlining of procedures to make this place work better.

The facts of the matter are that every year an increasing number of items come into this chamber, not just simply in terms of legislation but in terms of reports. We pass legislation which requires more reports. We pass legislation which requires more reference to the Parliament. We pass legislation that contains more disallowable instruments and so it goes on and on. We load more and more work on to this chamber, yet we seem to be unwilling to streamline our procedures to enable us to deal with it efficiently and effectively. There is no doubt that this chamber will resist sitting longer, so that is not an option. It already sits 30 per cent to 40 per cent longer than the House of Representatives and that is likely to continue, but we will not be sitting much longer than that. That is another element of this pamphlet that is wrong. It says that the pharmacists are using scare tactics on pensioners and other vulnerable members of the community. But it is really perestroika. Mr Gorbachev is moving in the opposite direction; he is seeking to restructure his administration and the public service to move to an era of improved efficiency and economies. This Government is restructuring the industries in this country in such a disastrous way, as other speakers today have said, that it can only be described as a form of social engineering. If Senator Crowley, Senator Giles and some of the others had said that the purpose of the Labor Government was to move the provision of health care to community health centres and public hospitals, and stated what the implications of the pharmacy arrangements were, they would at least have been honest. But no, they are hiding. Even in this instance, we have not once heard the word `restructuring' mentioned. Why? Most Darwin chemists will close if this goes ahead. This pharmacy would lose about $40,000 a year. We just couldn't afford to keep going. Only Darwin's biggest three pharmacies would survive the slashing of fees.
