What about the services that are so crucial in any suburban environment to the elderly? As I know from my own experience in a newsagency, the elderly enjoy shopping in those types of environments. They go to a newsagent for all sorts of social advice, and I can assure this chamber that they go to a pharmacy for a heck of a lot of medical advice and assistance and common sense. It does not cost them a penny but, of course, they do obtain their pharmaceutical requirements at the same time. This Government is proposing to pull that rug from under them and make them travel longer distances. Pharmacies do not survive just on their prescription counters; they supply a lot of other stock from the shelves. What is not being taken into account by this Government is that many of those other stock items have very slow movement but are there as part of the associated service. What about a pharmacist who outlays $70,000, $100,000 or $150,000 for his stock? What is the return on his capital, and what is the obligation that he has to meet for his borrowed finance at the rate of 21 per cent or 22 per cent that he currently has to pay because of the other economic policies of this Government?

In areas like the Northern Territory, which is remote and where there are long distances to travel, there are much higher set-up costs, staffing costs and freight costs for pharmacies which have to be added to the stock, yet this Government will come in and say to them, `Here is your price control'. Here is Labor, in its usual manner, going for price control and not allowing any margin that would be described as reasonable in any way. All of these things will have an impact on groups like the elderly which the Labor Party, traditionally, has said it is helping and supporting. That is a load of codswallop. In the Northern Territory a very significant proportion of the community is Aboriginal, and they need to call on the services of pharmacies at a higher rate than the general population. Again, this Government is making a mockery of itself by saying that it has a series of policies that assist disadvantaged people like Aboriginals. It certainly does not back up those concerns.

If communities like Katherine, Tennant Creek, Gove or Alice Springs lose any service in this area, it will be a dramatic and drastic change for them. I believe that in Tennant Creek and Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory there is only one pharmacist in each community, and they certainly cannot afford this type of drastic financial bastardry that is being carried on. In communities like Alice Springs and Darwin, where there are a number of pharmacies, a reduction in that number will provide a greater degree of inconvenience for the customers-the people that, I thought, the Labor Party would have been pleased to stand for and support in any way. But no, the Labor Government ignores them, puts them aside and says, `We are on a definite path of perestroika-of restructuring'. With what consequence? At what price? SPEECH.PARA: It is just incredible to me that this type of false economy has prompted this sort of pig-headed, incredibly aggressive governmental action. We ask: What are the motives? The people in Fairy Meadow-
of Wollongong-

hereby petition the Hawke Government to reverse its intent to proceed with the decision of the April economic statement covering the pharmaceutical benefits scheme that will result in the closure of many, if not the majority, of pharmacies in Australia. If this Government's proposal succeeds, it is quite clear that there will have to be a massive reduction in stockholdings by pharmacists. What are the consequences of stockholdings being reduced in pharmacies? If pharmacists hold reduced stock or if, in fact, they are out of stock, a patient wanting a prescription filled will have to wait until that stock is acquired. The patient will not be able to go around to the nearby pharmacy because that will be closed, courtesy of the Hawke Government. So the delivery of prescribed drugs to thousands of Australians--

TALK.START.PARA: —The closing of one pharmacy will not improve the economic circumstances of another.

—I take the point of the interjection. The closing of one pharmacy will not necessarily increase the economic status of another. In fact, on some prescriptions the pharmacist will actually lose money. The more business a pharmacist does the more he or she will lose.

SPEECH.PARA: If a pharmacist is going to be obliged to carry reduced stocks in order to cope with the reduced income that is going to be imposed, Australian consumers will suffer. To a massive extent, those Australian consumers are women of whom a large proportion are aged and, in many instances, infirm. Is this yet another example of this Government kicking the most defenceless sector of Australian society? It seems that it is. What possible benefit can there be to consumers in reducing the amount of access that they have to the pharmaceutical products that they require? What benefit can there be to consumers if they are forced to use a reduced number of outlets with reduced levels of stock which may not be able immediately to meet their needs?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister calls them `silly old buggers'.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that pharmacies are not ripping off the taxpayer. They are not inefficient. In fact, it has been acknowledged that there have been significant increases in the efficiency of the pharmacy industry. Pharmacists have achieved productivity gains in their practices. No-one doubts this. The Government has not come up with any evidence to the contrary. In fact, the increased application of computers, for example, has resulted in significant increases in productivity and efficiency in the pharmaceutical industry. Of course, pharmacists have to pay for this kind of equipment. So the reward--

TALK.START.PARA: —And pay interest.

—As Senator Patterson notes, they have to pay interest at the huge rates that are now applying because of this Government's incompetent economic activities. But the efforts of pharmacists to install equipment in order to improve efficiency are rewarded by huge reductions in income. In many instances, this will result in closures.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the Government that pharmacists provide after-hours services. Generally, a few pharmacists band together and draw up a roster. The pharmacy industry is providing this service which did not exist some years ago. Pharmacists make deliveries to pensioners at home, in nursing homes or in hospitals. Often, at significant cost to themselves, they dispense and take drugs to people who desperately need them. It is important to note that pharmacists play an enormous role in counselling and giving advice to the public. They charge absolutely nothing for this service. This cost comes out of the meagre profits that they are supposed to earn from dispensing prescriptions. Many pharmacists could not survive unless they went into a mini-supermarket situation. He interposes himself sensibly and effectively between the doctor, who possibly could make a mistake, and the consumer who is, in so many instances, a pensioner. As I said, my concerns about this legislation relate to people-the people in pharmacy itself and the people who are the consumers of pharmacy. That is why I will be supporting the Opposition's very strong position that the amendments that were passed last time by the Senate, effectively blocking what the Government is seeking to do, should be passed once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise at this stage of the committee debate in order to reply to some of the nonsense and misleading statements that have been made by senators opposite. I think the last speech in many respects distilled some of the stupidity of the Opposition's position nicely. We had from Senator Michael Baume a heart tugging eulogy to the enterprise and individuality-the entrepreneurial flair, which he alluded to-of individual pharmacists. I do not deny that there is a degree of small business character about pharmacies, but it is not in the pharmacy side. I point out that the entrepreneurial flair-the bright light of free enterprise, so to speak, in pharmacies-was supported last year by $1.5 billion of taxpayers' money. We can talk about free enterprise propped up by $1.5 billion, but that has nothing to do with entrepreneurial flair.

SPEECH.PARA: It is because this Government pays to pharmacies around Australia $1.5 billion in subsidies that we have this issue. That is the basis of this Government's interest. We have a large public expenditure, we are accountable to taxpayers as to how that money is used and we want to be sure that it is used properly. It should be used properly for pharmacists as well as for the wider community which foots the bill in the end. That is why we supported a Liberal Party Bill back in 1981 to provide independent arbitration on the level of fees. The level of fees-that is the amount of taxpayers' money that supports pharmacies-is not a blank cheque, it is arrived at by a process of proper procedure, of listening to the arguments, surveying the costs, and then making a considered decision. That is why in the 1981 legislation that members of the Liberal Party were then pleased to bring into this chamber they insisted that there be a clause that would bind the Government so that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal would be genuinely independent and free.

That is why we have a hands-off arrangement under the separation of powers concept vested in an independent tribunal which has the right to make a decision which fixes the level of remuneration for pharmacists and is thus a guide to how much the public purse is at stake in terms of this issue. Why do we pay that money? We pay it because this Government is concerned about ordinary Australians, more particularly about age pensioners, people in need of medication, and the poor. If we did not subsidise pharmacies in order to keep their costs contained and if the market fixed the price-Senator Michael Baume has spoken about this and Senator Knowles ran off at the mouth about it earlier-at which drugs were supplied to the community, the poor would not be able to afford medical treatment, those who are chronically ill and require medication would not be able to afford it either, and people who have problems with diabetes, for example, would not be able to afford their insulin.

The reason why we put the money in is to ensure equity of access for the community so that irrespective of means, of whether a person is wealthy or poor, chronically ill or healthy, he has an entitlement to the medication. That is the fundamental reason this Government is involved in this issue and that is why it is important. Because it is so important and because such a huge amount of public funds is involved there has to be a regulatory mechanism. What we are confronted with here is this: the regulatory mechanism has worked, an inquiry has been conducted, a survey was taken, argument was put, facts were adduced, and an independent inquiry came to a decision. That normally would be unexceptional and would require simply that the fact be noted and that we pass to the next subject. But because the decision was not to the liking of one of the major groups affected, pharmacists-some pharmacists but not all because there is a lot of morality and good sense among a number of pharmacists I have met-protested and it then became a question not of whether due process would prevail, not whether an adjudication, independent and untainted by political force would be made and decided, but who could generate the greatest industrial muscle, the greatest community conflict and who could bring the greatest weight to bear. These matters were not determined ethically; they were determined on who had the most horsepower in terms of pressure.

As I have said before, this Government will not buckle to that pressure and the pharmacists who are part of this campaign will not succeed in imposing for themselves a 40 per cent wage hike, which is what they want, and nor will we allow it. Indeed, many of the pharmacists do not want to do that now either.

Mr Matthews-
according to the introductory paragraph he is the National President of the Guild-
said that the Guild acknowledges that the Tribunal's determination is legally binding on pharmacists and Government . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the adjournment debate I want to say a few words about an area that is remote from Australia-Eritrea and Ethiopia-which I have spoken about previously. Exactly 12 months ago I visited Eritrea as a guest of the Eritrean Relief Association and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front. When I returned to Australia in November last year I made a speech in the Senate, so I do not need to go over my experiences and what I observed at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: At long last, after 27 years of military conflict between the Eritreans and Ethiopians, there is some small hope that a political settlement can be reached between them. In September this year an ex-President of the United States of America, Jimmy Carter, arranged a meeting in Atlanta in the State of Georgia so that both sides could come together to begin some preliminary talks. This was the first time in about 26 years that both sides agreed to talk without preconditions. Some would say that the talks were not successful because they did not reach a settlement of the dispute, but I do not think that anybody who has made any attempt to follow the intricacies of the dispute between Eritrea and Ethiopia expected agreement to be reached at one sitting of talks in view of the long and intractable war that has been fought between the people of those countries.

However, the most pleasing thing about the talks was that, despite still many disagreements, they agreed to further talks in various places in Africa over the period of the next 12 months or so. Under the chairmanship of ex-President Jimmy Carter they agreed that the next round of talks would begin on 18 November, next month, in Nairobi, Kenya. A list of further venues has been announced for possible further talks. None of us who show any interest in the situation in Eritrea and Ethiopia would expect that there will be a rapid conclusion to the talks and that a settlement will be reached, but we have all encouraged these talks to take place. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the final communique and attached notes issued at the end of the talks held in Atlanta in September.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Appendix XVIII
September 19, 1989
FINAL COMMUNIQUE

The delegations of the government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front have conducted several days of constructive and productive discussions. In accordance with our agreement to make a complete public record, the exact language of these agreements is being made available to the press. A summary is given below:
1. Both sides have demonstrated that there is a genuine commitment to the peace process and a determination to continue the effort to a successful conclusion.

2. Notwithstanding the absolute right of freedom of speech, the parties will endeavour to make only constructive statements to the press or public so long as the peace process is proceeding in a positive fashion.
3. Both sides may use Amharic, Arabic, or other languages of their choice, to be translated into English, the working language.

4. A complete record of the proceedings will be kept, and both sides will be furnished with copies of magnetic tape recordings, plus a written transcript of the discussions in English as soon as possible. Following each negotiating session or round of talks, these transcripts may be made public by either side.
5. For future negotiating sessions, as in Atlanta, there will be no pre-conditions, the public will be kept informed, and there will be full-time third party participation.

6. Sites for negotiating sessions in rotation will be Nairobi, Khartoum, Sana'a, Cairo, Arusha, and Harare. The chairman/co-chairmen will select the venue for each negotiating session after consulting with the two sides.
7. Observers will be invited to attend meetings. There is some disagreement on the selection and role of observers, as will be explained later.

8. Chairman-Co-chairmen will be chosen by the negotiating parties, whose duties will be to arrange meetings and schedules, to open and close meetings, to chair the meetings, to rule on points of order, and to assure that meetings are conducted smoothly and properly. These duties will be performed without prejudice or partiality, and with the approval of the negotiating parties.

9. On each agenda item, each side will present its initial views in writing to the other side. Then there will be a thorough discussion of the issue until agreement is reached. If the two sides cannot agree, then co-chairmen shall use their good offices to mediate disagreements by putting forward proposals for consideration by the negotiating parties.
There are remaining disagreements on the chairmanship and mediation which will be explained later.

10. A staff or secretariat will be necessary to assist the chairman/co-chairman in the peace process. Members of the staff will be proposed by the chairman/co-chairmen and approved by the negotiating parties. Either negotiating party may propose members of the secretariat to be considered by the chairmen for service. There are remaining disagreements that will be explained later.
11. Rules of procedure will be as suggested by the chairman/co-chairmen and secretariat, with the approval of both negotiating parties.

12. Delegations for future talks will consist of not more than twelve on each side. Identity of the negotiating teams will be exchanged in advance, at least two weeks prior to the convening of each negotiating session. Each side may change membership in its negotiating team after prior notice to the co-chairmen and the other side.
13. The agenda for the main talks will be as follows:
(a) Opening statement by the co-chairmen.
(b) Welcoming remarks by the Head of State in the host country.
(c) Opening statements by the chairmen of both negotiating teams.
(d) Approval of agreements reached in the preliminary talks
(e) The resolution of issues of disagreement in the Atlanta talks.
(f) Adoption of agenda for main talks. Initial proposals are to be given in writing by both sides.
(g) Final communique.
(h) Closing ceremony.
Chairmanship:

We have agreed on duties and functions of the chairman/co-chairmen. These are the points in dispute: One of the chairmen must be an African leader of one of the countries of venue. The parties have not reached agreement on who that co-chairman will be.

The position of the EPLF is that ``The chairman shall be President Carter. The co-chairmen shall be designated by the chairman from among the heads of state of the venue countries on rotation basis. They, in return, can designate persons of their own choice.''
The position of the Ethiopian government is that there be two equal and permanent co-chairmen, one of whom will be an African leader of one of the countries of venue.

My own role in the continuation of these negotiations will depend on the selection of a suitable African chairman. I am unwilling to serve until the decision on the African leader has been made. No African leader will be willing to serve unless he is satisfied with our agreements in Atlanta and knows that he is acceptable to both sides. If either of the original choices is unable to serve, others will be chosen, by mutual consent of the negotiating parties.
Observers:

My latest compromise proposal is as follows: Initially, there will be seven observers, and others will be invited to attend. Of the seven, each side may choose two observers without restriction and without the expression of reservations by the other side. Three others will be invited by mutual agreement. Additional countries may be represented by observers, with mutual agreement by the two sides.''
The EPLF accepts with the understanding that there will be no expression or reservation regarding the unrestricted choices and that the observers may serve as mediators.
The Ethiopian government accepts with the understanding that reservations may be expressed regarding the unrestricted choices and that the observers will serve as witnesses.
Secretariat:
There are questions concerning the source of the staff and their role as mediators.
The EPLF insists that the Carter Center, the OAU, and Sudan will provide members of the secretariat and that the last named members will officially represent the OAU and Sudan.
The Ethiopian side insists that the co-chairmen will choose the staff or secretariat and that these serve in their individual capacities.

Concerning the role of observers and staff, my compromise proposal for consideration by both sides is: ``In addition to the co-chairmen, others will be needed to serve as mediators. Observers and members of the secretariat who have already been approved by both sides will be the most likely choices. Once chosen, mediators will continue to serve so long as they are mutually acceptable to both sides.

Although complete agreement has not been reached on all issues in these preliminary talks in Atlanta, both sides have agreed to continue this effort. I have been authorized to set the time and place for the next talks. My preference is that these peace efforts be recessed until November 18, at which time we reconvene in Nairobi, Kenya. In the meantime, the two sides will be asked to seek agreement on the remaining issues, to propose their list of observers, and to agree on an African leader to serve with me in the main talks.
Jimmy Carter
Appendix XIV
I. Agreement Regarding Publicity

Both the representatives of the Government and the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree to the following principles concerning publicity during the peace process:
1. Every party has an absolute right of freedom of speech.

2. Notwithstanding the right of freedom of speech, the parties agree that so long as the peace process is proceeding in a positive fashion and the parties have confidence in the process, then the parties will only make constructive statements to the press concerning the peace process.

3. Each party has the right to demand that a joint communique be issued publicly at any time during the peace process. The parties will work together in good faith to try to reach agreement on the terms of said communique. If either side feels the communique is not satisfactory, it is free to issue its own statement.
II. Agreement Regarding Working Languages

Both the representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree to the following principles concerning working languages during the peace process:
1. During the negotiating sessions the parties may speak in the language of their choice including Amharic, Arabic or others. Their statements shall be interpreted into English.
2. The official records of the peace process will be maintained in English, including the transcripts of the parties' statements and all written agreements.
III. Agreement Regarding Official Records

Both the representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree to the following principles concerning official records during the peace process:
1. All records of all negotiating sessions will be maintained on magnetic tape.
2. The originals of the records will be maintained by the chairman or co-chairmen.
3. True copies of all recordings will be given to each of the negotiating parties as soon as possible, preferably at the end of each day.
4. Transcripts of all negotiating sessions will be maintained and made available to each party.
IV. Agreement Regarding Venue

Both the representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree to the following principles concerning the venue during the peace process:
Negotiating sessions will be held in rotation in Khartoum (Sudan), Cairo (Egypt), Sana'a (Yemen Arab Republic), Nairobi (Kenya), Arusha (Tanzania) and Harare (Zimbabwe).
The location of each specific negotiating session will be made by mutual agreement of the parties.
V. Points of Departure Between the Two Parties Regarding Chairman/Chairmen

1. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that Former President Jimmy Carter be the chairman of the peace process. The co-chairmen should be chosen by the chairman and should be a rotating position. The co-chairmen should be the head-of-state of the country of venue for the current round of negotiations, e.g. Sudan, Egypt, Yemen Arab Republic, Kenya, Tanzania and Zimbabwe.

The Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia proposes that Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Julius Nyerere serve as permanent co-chairmen of the peace process. Should either be unable to serve, the substitute co-chairmen could be chosen from among the heads-of-state of the country of venue for the current round of negotiations, e.g. Sudan, Egypt, Yemen Arab Republic, Kenya, Tanzania and Zimbabwe.

2. The Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia proposes that in order to expedite the proceedings and to assist in resolving disagreements, the co-chairmen shall use their good offices, when necessary, to mediate between the negotiating parties by putting forward proposals for consideration by the negotiating parties.

The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that the mediation role should be performed not only by the chairmen, but also by the observers, the secretariat and outside powers including the United States and the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics. These mediators could constitute a body which could undertake the mediation role. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front believes that there is a need for strong mediation and that the chairmen alone cannot play the role.
The Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia does not object to other heads-of-state from the countries of venue performing mediation roles provided there is mutual agreement.
VI. Points of Departure Between the Two Parties Regarding the Staff or Secretariat.

1. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that the chairman should select the members of the secretariat from among the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League, the Sudan Government and the Carter Center. The secretariat should serve in representative capacities and not in personal capacities.
The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that members of the secretariat should perform mediation roles between the parties and help in decision making.

The Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia proposes that the chairmen should choose the secretariat in any way deemed appropriate. The secretariat should perform staff roles and not mediate between the parties.
VII. Points of Departure Between the Two Parties Regarding Observers.

1. The Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia proposes that the number of observers will be limited to seven governments. Of these, either side can unilaterally select two without restriction. The other three will be chosen by mutual consent from among the countries of venue, e.g. Sudan, Egypt, Yemen Arab Republic, Kenya, Tanzania and Zimbabwe.

The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that the observers represent the Governments of Sudan, Egypt, Kenya, Yemen Arab Republic, Nigeria, Kuwait, Pakistan, Italy, the United Kingdom, Sweden and Australia. Additionally, the regional organizations of the Organization of African Unity and the Arab League should also observe.
2. Alternately, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League and the United Nations serve as observers.
3. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front proposes that the observers should perform a mediation role between the parties.
VIII. Agreement Regarding the Rules of Procedure

The representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree that the chairman or co-chairmen will set the rules of procedure for the peace process which will be mutually acceptable to the parties. In this decision, they will look to the rules of international organizations.
IX, X. Agreement Regarding the Time, Place and Agenda of the Next Talks

The representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree that the chairman or co-chairmen may choose the venue for the next talks from among the agreed list of countries of venue.
The time of the next talks will be November 18, 1989 in Nairobi, Kenya.
These talks will be scheduled to resolve points of disagreement between the parties remaining from the Atlanta negotiating session.
XI. Agreement Regarding the Agenda for the Main Talks
The representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree that the agenda for the next talks will be as follows:
1. Opening statements by the chairmen or co-chairmen.
2. Welcoming remarks by the head-of-state of the host country.
3. Opening statements by the chairmen of both negotiating teams.
4. Approval of agreements reached in the preliminary talks.
5. Resolution of issues of disagreement in the Atlanta talks.
6. Adoption of agenda for main talks.
7. Final communique.
8. Closing ceremony.
XII. Agreement Regarding Delegations

Both the representatives of the Government of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front agree that delegations for future talks will consist of not more than twelve on each side. Identity of the negotiating teams will be exchanged in advance, at least two weeks prior to the convening of each negotiating session. Each side may change membership in its negotiating team after prior notice to the chairman or co-chairmen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the courtesy of allowing me to incorporate that communique in Hansard although it is several pages long. In view of the long conflict in Eritrea I believe it is a small concession for the Senate to allow that communique and the attached notes to be incorporated in its official record. I want to draw attention to one thing in particular in the communique. I am pleased that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is the duty Minister at the moment. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front was asked to suggest a list of possible observer countries that could attend the talks in Nairobi and listed Australia among a dozen such countries. That is a recognition by the Eritreans of the humanitarian role that Australia has played in the region over recent years. While the Minister is present in the chamber I ask him and the Australian Government to give serious consideration, if Australia is finally asked and is able to act as an observer at the talks in Nairobi, to accepting that invitation and request to arrange for a representative to be present. We have an embassy in Nairobi and I do not think it would be too difficult to arrange for one of the officers to be present at those talks.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Eritreans have asked for Australia to be considered as one of the observer countries because of the role Australia has played in recent years in providing humanitarian aid to the region. I do not have the exact figures with me, but certainly since about 1983-84 several million dollars in humanitarian aid has been given to both the Eritreans and the Ethiopians during the bad droughts that have taken place. Certainly, on my visit to Eritrea last year I observed that the ordinary Eritrean people all know what the magnificent contribution of the Australian people, through their Government, meant and that many of them were able to survive the dreadful droughts of 1984-85. I think we can all be proud of the role we have played.

Unfortunately, I have just received information that this year the region is again facing a serious drought and that again the people of Ethiopia and Eritrea will possibly be calling on Australia to provide appropriate levels of humanitarian aid. Even though we have a tight aid budget I hope that the Australian Government, through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) and the non-government organisations, can again arrange for appropriate aid to be provided.

It should be pointed out that in Eritrea alone 600,000 to 700,000 people have been uprooted because of the ferocious fighting and are now living in very primitive refugee camp conditions. If there is a severe drought, as now appears likely, these people will be utterly dependent upon aid from countries such as Australia. I raise that matter for the Minister's comment. I have already written to him and to AIDAB requesting that consideration be given to making preparations for what could be an impending human disaster in the Horn of Africa.

Finally, I refer to the general situation in the Horn of Africa-again, an area remote from the interests of most Australians. But I think that in the Sudan, Eritrea, Somalia and Djibouti we have the worst area of human misery in the world at the moment-I suspect even worse than Cambodia. There are more displaced people in that area than in any other area in the world. People in southern Sudan are fleeing into Ethiopia because of the civil war being fought within the Sudan between the Arab and negro races. Refugees from Ethiopia are fleeing into Sudan. Refugees not only from Eritrea but also from the Tigre province, the Osmol province and the Ogaden area of Ethiopia are fleeing into Somalia. Conversely, all but a civil war is now being fought in areas of Somalia and refugees are fleeing from Somalia into Ethiopia and Djibouti.

All in all, the ordinary people in that area are facing a dreadful prospect. Most people in the Western world are ignorant of that area because of the lack of information coming out of it. Recently I had the opportunity to be briefed by an Australian woman, Ms Valerie Browning, who has spent some time in Somalia. Her account of the horrors of Somalia at the moment are quite devastating. But it is interesting that Australia is being asked to consider assistance in those areas and also to participate in trying to find a peaceful settlement to the various military conflicts. The military conflicts in the area are partly as a result of the underlying poverty and deprivation of the people in those various countries. It is a vicious cycle: high levels of poverty lead to military conflict and people, desperate to try to find ways to overcome it, are resorting to military activity, which further compounds poverty and despair.

I welcome the opportunity to put on record tonight that at least there has been one small step forward in one area of the conflict in the Horn of Africa between Eritrea and Ethiopia. Talks are taking place and we should congratulate ex-President Carter for showing the initiative in convincing both sides to come to the negotiating table and at least getting a commitment that the talks will be ongoing. I reiterate that, if Australia is asked to participate as an observer in these talks, I hope that the Foreign Minister and the Government can respond positively so that we can play a role commensurate with our interest in providing humanitarian aid over a number of years to this unhappy area of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to tell the Senate the story of Margaret. This is at her request. Margaret wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 15 August 1989 and to date has had no reply. In her letter Margaret describes how she was sentenced to 18 years of child abuse because a government did not like the colour of her skin. She describes in her letter how she was born as the result of a pack rape. Her mother was raped at the age of 16 by a group of Afghan camel traders who were in the northern parts of Western Australia. Margaret was made a State ward and spent the first 18 years of her life in an orphanage where she describes herself as having been mentally, physically and sexually abused. In her letter to the Prime Minister, Margaret tells him that she has documents to prove what happened to her and says that she was in a state of shock when she found out that it was the colour of her skin that deprived her of a family. She describes in her letter how she feels that she was sentenced to 18 years for an offence that was committed by others. She says in her letter that every lawyer who has seen her papers has also been shocked.

SPEECH.PARA: Margaret has had access to her papers since October 1988. Although, of course, it is admirable that she finally was given access to her papers, she was not given counselling at the time and this has been responsible for a lot of the distress that she has felt since that time. She concludes her letter to the Prime Minister:
Where Mr Prime Minister is my Justice?

I have copies here of the documents to which Margaret was given access in October 1988. At the conclusion of my speech I will seek to table these documents, but during my speech I will quote selectively from them. The first document is dated 24 April 1944, which was the year that Margaret was born. This is presumably the first report on her in the foundling orphanage to which she was taken. A report dated 1960 says of her, `No visitors. Has no ability. Does not mix over-well. Has no relatives? Is dark skinned but features not negroid'. Another report is dated 20 June 1949 and reads:

I visited Margaret . . . at the . . . Foundling Home. Margaret is a dear little girl but she definitely has some coloured blood. I believe her father was a maori. Under the circumstances Margaret would not be suitable for adoption but perhaps it would be advisable if possible to place her in a private home.

This report was noted by some four or five people and Margaret has written at the bottom of this document, `This document has devastated me'. The next document is dated 8 May 1958 in which an inspectress of the Welfare Branch wrote:
I saw Margaret . . . at . . . Orphanage.
Margaret is a half caste. She is doing well at school and reported to be a very good lass.

The next document is dated 14 July 1959 in which she is described, among other things, as being in the seventh standard, `tall', `pleasant looking girl', `healthy', `does not really look abo' and `never any visitors'. The last document, which is a letter to Margaret from the Child Welfare Department, is dated 2 May 1962. The then Director of the Child Welfare Department wrote to Margaret saying:
Dear Margaret,
I would like to wish you many happy returns for your eighteenth birthday, which was on the 24th April . . .
No doubt you realise that your term as a ward expired on that date . . .
Once again I say all the best of luck for your future from your friends of the Child Welfare Department.

We then move on to 1988 and I make known to the Senate a letter from a senior social worker at the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital in Perth to the Minister for Community Services, Mrs Hallahan. The letter reads as follows:
Dear Mrs Hallahan,

. . . is a 44 year old woman who is currently an in-patient in the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, Department Psychiatry and Behavioural Science. . . . was recently admitted after a disclosure from her mother identifying that her birth was the result of a pack rape when . . . 's mother was 16 years of age. . . . as a consequence of Margaret's mother's inability or refusal to contribute to her care, Margaret was made a Ward of the Department of Child Welfare in 1946, at the age of 2 1/2 years. Margaret lived for the following 18 years at the . . . Foundling Home and described the treatment that she received there as being brutal and abusive. Margaret spent a brief period fostered with a woman in Maylands and described this experience likewise, as being horrific.

Margaret has recently been made aware that she was ineligible for adoption because she was considered to be coloured. She is understandably considerably angry and enraged by this information as she believes that the subsequent period spent at . . . and in foster homes to be a direct consequence of this attitude and decision.
Margaret is keen to establish some sense of social justice for herself and feels extremely victimised . . .
It then lists a number of reasons and continues:

To assist Margaret to reconcile these experiences of her birth, childhood and adolescence, I wondered if you may be available to meet with Margaret and provide her with some information regarding her earlier life experiences so as to assist her to appreciate that the attitude of some of the authority figures in her life has been one of caring and compassion.

That last letter is dated 28 February 1989 and is from the Assistant Director-General of the Western Australian State Department for Community Services. It is written to the senior social worker at the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital and states:
I am writing as a follow-up to our meeting with Miss . . . on 10 February.
From my perspective the discussion was an extremely valuable one and highlighted many important issues for this Department.

The most important of these is our responsibilities to children entrusted to our care and protection. Although there have been dramatic changes since the time that Miss . . . was a child in care, the issue of abuse of children in substitute care situations is still a critical one, which requires our priority attention on an ongoing basis.
As per our telephone conversation, I have spoken to . . ., the Coordinator of the Western Institute for Self Help-
known as WISH in Western Australia-

She is very keen to support the establishment of a self help group for people who have suffered similar damaging experiences in substitute care. In fact she has recently been contacted by a woman who has relayed similar stories about her treatment in another children's home around the same period.
Our Department will also be keen to offer whatever support is appropriate . . .
The name of a contact person in the Department for Community Services is then given. The letter continues:

She would also be able to link people into other services as appropriate. For example, I have asked the Department's Principal Clinical Psychologist to consider appropriate avenues for making counselling services available either within the Department or by external counsellors.
I would think though that the most appropriate first step would be to form the self help group to provide a means of linking together people with similar circumstances . . .

The issue of the need for sensitivity in the handling of information has been taken up with the Manager of the Information and Public Affairs section who is very keen to ensure that the distress caused to Miss . . . is not repeated in the future.

Finally, I would ask you to thank Miss . . . for bringing these very important issues to attention. The very balanced way in which she presented the issues in spite of the enormous personal suffering she has endured showed tremendous character and discipline.

As a result of Margaret's initiatives, the support group has now been formed. The group is anxious to alert others that it exists for people who need and want to join. The group wants every opportunity to be given to people who need that assistance. It has a standard letter which goes out to the people which says:
We have started a support group for adults who at one time in their childhood spent time in a Government or non Government institution.

As you may or may not know Institutional child abuse did happen on a large scale, not all the children suffered child abuse but the ones who did left these Institutions as young adults, and to this day have not been able to talk about what happened to them, whenever they talked about the abuse they received in these Institutions nobody would believe them, when they left these Institutions there was no follow up, nobody cared about what happened to them.

There were about eleven Child Welfare Officers to seventeen Government and non Government Institutions. In each institution there were about 200 to 300 upwards children. We want your help to let them know I.C.A.S.G.-
the Institutional Child Abuse Support Group-
will help them to come to terms with the abuse they received in these Institutions.

I have met Margaret and have spoken to her at length. She is a delightfully articulate and vivacious woman. Margaret feels that she has now made it, but she does not want others to suffer in the way that she did. Margaret is very proud to be the initiating force behind the ICASG. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it is at Margaret's instigation that I bring these matters to public notice because she feels that others can be helped and certainly need not hide any more behind the curtains of their homes, that they can go out and meet and talk with others and receive the assistance that is now available through the State Government of Western Australia. I would like finally to commend the State Government for initiating the self-help group and giving assistance to make it possible. I seek leave to table the documents from which I quoted selectively.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am on my feet-because I feel it was not understood when I spoke earlier-I would like to speak on the issue of the drug, Depromedrol, which has been used epidurally. TALK.START.PARA: —Two speeches have been made in the adjournment debate tonight. We are indebted firstly to Senator Jenkins for bringing to our attention the very moving tale of Margaret. The particular problem that has been identified is a very widespread one in the community but too often a hidden one. I think the kind of service which has been done by Senator Jenkins and the lady in question in helping to bring this out into public exposure is very useful for the community as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Schacht's contribution on Eritrea is concerned, the Government will certainly take carefully into account the suggestions he has made or will be making to me about the possible Australian role in trying to bring to an end the terrible conflict in that country. Australia recognises Ethiopia as a sovereign state within its internationally recognised boundaries, and as such has not been in a position to take sides, other than in a way that recognises that sovereignty. We acknowledge the awful pressures and the tragedy that has occurred within the country over the years of conflict, and in particular in the years of drought that have been so devastating. We have made a major financial contribution over recent years to try to alleviate some of the distress associated with the food shortages. It may be-although I certainly make no such commitment at this stage-that we can play some other role in helping in the context of the negotiations that are mercifully now occurring and contribute towards some resolution of the situation. I thank Senator Schacht for his contribution to the debate also.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 7 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, under Australia Post's new policy relating to registered publications, periodical publications with a cover price of more than $5 may no longer be mailed as registered publications.
(2) What reason or justification can the Minister give for the nexus between the cover price of a magazine and the postal rate.

(3) Is it a fact that specialist literary journals, environmental publications, and arts magazines will have their postage rates increased by 200 to 300 per cent under the new policy; if so, is this in accord with Government policy regarding the arts, literature, and the environment.
(4) How many such magazines whose eligibility will be removed are registered with Australia Post.
(5) How much money does Australia Post expect to save, given that sorting and handling of registered items is done by the sender.
(6) What costing was done by Australia Post before introducing the new policy.
(7) What consultation, and with whom, did the Minister have before introducing the new pricing policy.
(8) What steps will the Minister take to improve the situation for specialist publishers, who have traditionally relied on the registered postage system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Australia Post:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The answer is ``Yes'' for magazines being registered after October 1989; however publications are registered annually so existing publications with a cover price exceeding $5 will not be affected until their next annual renewal occurs after 1 October 1989.

(2) The terms and conditions of eligibility for the registered publications service are a matter for the Board of Australia Post. This provision was contained in legislation recently passed by the Parliament. Australia Post has advised that the cover price limit is appropriate because it is an objective criterion and does not require subjective judgements by post office staff. Also cover price is a measure of a customer's capacity to pay the full postage.

(3) Publications in the 100-250 grams weight step that would otherwise enjoy subsidised postage of 37 cents will be liable for the full postage of $1.10 for interstate delivery; the figures for publications in the 250-500 grams weight step are 47 cents and $2.10 respectively. However, some publications affected by the new criterion may be eligible for Australia Post's published discounts. Australia Post's proposals to reduce losses incurred on the registered publications service (see answer to part 5) are consistent with its statutory obligation to perform its functions in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice.

(4) The exact number is not known because Australia Post has not previously required publishers to state the cover price when applying for registration. However, Australia Post estimates that the number will be less than 150, ie less than 1% of publications initially, and not all of the 150 magazines fall within the category of publications referred to in (3).
(5) This measure is part of a package designed to contain the loss on the registered publications service and reduce it by half over the next 3 years. The loss in 1988-89 is estimated at $21 million.

(6) In April 1989 Australia Post submitted its proposals for registered publications to the Scrutiny of the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). The proposals were considered at the PSA's public enquiry in May 1989. A wide variety of organisations took the opportunity to make submissions to the PSA.
(7) Australia Post provided advice of the change to publishers in April 1989. This was in addition to the public evidence provided to the PSA.

(8) It is open to specialist publishers to negotiate postal arrangements for their publications with Australia Post. The question of special assistance for the distribution requirements of specialist publications is a matter for the appropriate Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that the then U.S. President (Mr Nixon) gave each head of friendly governments a moon rock.
(2) Who received the rock on behalf of Australia and where is it kept.
(3) Is it available for research work and is it available for public exhibition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Moon rock fragments were presented to Prime Minister John Gorton as a gift to the Australian people from President Richard Nixon on 14 January 1970. Although commonly referred to as a moon rock the presentation consisted of a number of small fragments of moon rock contained in a small dome on a wooden stand. There were presentations to other governments but details of these are not known.

(2) The presentation was made to Prime Minister Gorton by Astronaut Colonel Thomas Stafford during the visit to Australia by Vice-President Spiro Agnew. The moon rock fragments were transferred to the custody of Australian Archives in 1978. They are held at the Archives ACT Regional Office.

(3) Access to or public exhibition of the moon rock fragments would be in accordance with the provisions of the Archives Act 1983. A larger moon rock sample presented in 1974 is held by the Museum of Australia and is available for public exhibition. Separate moon rock samples have been made available by NASA to Australian scientists for research purposes.
